questions.text: A team of researchers is investigating different mechanisms for transmitting sensory information via neurons. They isolate free nerve endings from skin tissue that transmit pain via type C nerve fibers. Which of the following describes a characteristic of these nerve fibers?

choices.text: They are found in the lens of the eye

questions.solution:
Type C nerve fibers are tiny, unmyelinated fibers used by free nerve endings to transmit pain and temperature from the skin and viscera. Since these fibers are unmyelinated, they transmit the sensory information slowly compared to their myelinated counterparts.  

Option Analysis

❌ They are found in the lens of the eye:
Incorrect: Type C nerve fibers are only present in the skin and viscera.  
❌ Small, myelinated fibers:
Incorrect: Small myelinated fibers are responsible for transmitting temperature sensation in type A-delta nerve fibers.  
✅ Small, unmyelinated fibers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Large, myelinated fibers:
Incorrect: Examples of large, myelinated fibers include Pacinian and Meissner corpuscles located in the deep skin layers and Glabrous (hairless) skin. These fibers function to sense fine touch, vibration, and pressure.  
❌ Large, unmyelinated fibers:
Incorrect: Large unmyelinated fibers can be seen with nerve endings that transmit instinctive pain and temperature in the skin and viscera via type B fibers.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of disturbed smell sensation. Yesterday his mother found the gas stove turned on, and the patient was unable to smell the odor. He had a bilateral orchiopexy due to cryptorchidism in infancy. The patient takes no medications daily and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Height is at the third percentile for age, with 4.8 cm (1.9 in) of growth noted in the last year. Visual fields are intact. There is no breast tissue, axillary, or pubic hair. The genitals are at Tanner stage 1. Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with delayed puberty and anosmia consistent with the diagnosis of Kallmann syndrome, which results from the impaired migration of GnRH neurons from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus.   

During fetal development, two groups of neurons emerge from a region of the brain called the olfactory placode. The first group of neurons migrate down from the olfactory placode, embed in the cribriform plate, and assist with sensing smell. The second group of neurons migrate through the cribriform plate to settle in the hypothalamus, where they release gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). GnRH further stimulates luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion from the pituitary gland, inducing the gonads to produce sex specific hormones (i.e., estrogen and progesterone in women and testosterone in men).  

Kallmann syndrome results from a defect in the migration of the neurons from the olfactory placode including the olfactory neurons (CN I) and GnRH neurons which results in a ↓ in GnRH, FSH, LH and testosterone/estrogen, and progesterone. As a result, patients present with under-developed primary and secondary sex characteristics, delayed onset puberty, anosmia/hyposmia, and midline defects (e.g., cleft lip or palate).  



Option Analysis

❌ Sex chromosome trisomy:
Incorrect: Klinefelter syndrome is a sex chromosome trisomy (XXY) that presents with delayed puberty in a male patient. However, these patients characteristically have a tall, slender frame and gynecomastia. Moreover, the features in this adolescent (anosmia and history of cryptorchidism) are not explained by Klinefelter syndrome.  
❌ Compression of pituitary stalk:
Incorrect: A craniopharyngioma can delay the onset of puberty by compressing the pituitary stalk and interfering with normal pituitary function. This patient has none of the classical symptoms associated with this diagnosis including visual field defects, hyperprolactinemia, or central diabetes insipidus.  
❌ Hyperprolactinemia:
Incorrect: Hyperprolactinemia can present with hypogonadism in men, which could explain this patient's Tanner 1 genital development. However, lack of testosterone typically causes gynecomastia, which is not observed in this patient. The most common cause of this condition is a prolactinoma that presents with additional symptoms of mass effect (e.g., headache, bitemporal hemianopsia, diplopia).  
✅ Impaired migration of GnRH neurons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Use of exogenous androgenic substances:
Incorrect: Anabolic steroid use can lead to impaired testicular function with decreased testicular size and lowered sperm count. It does not lead to sparse facial/body hair or anosmia.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate pain and redness of the left eye for the past three days. The patient is a school teacher and recalls exposure to a child with “pink eye.” The patient does not have any associated fever, cough, headache, nasal congestion, or sore throat. The patient was recently diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis after evaluating chronic back pain. She does not take any medications except for ibuprofen as needed. Family history is significant for acute-angle closure glaucoma in the patient’s mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Ocular examination findings are shown below.



Reproduced fromWikimedia Commons

During the examination, the patient could not keep her left eye open. Increased tearing is noted from the left eye. The right eye examination is within normal limits. Visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye and 20/20 in the right eye. Which component of the eye is implicated in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a painful red eye, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity suggestive of anterior uveitis, which refers to inflammation of the anterior uveal tract (i.e. the iris and ciliary body). Physical examination demonstrates ciliary flush, a hazy flare in the aqueous humor, and hypopyon (exudate rich in white blood cells). This condition can be idiopathic or secondary to systemic autoimmune disorders, including ankylosing spondylitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, Reiter syndrome, sarcoidosis, or Behçet disease.

In contrast, posterior uveitis, which refers to inflammation of the posterior uveal tract (choroid and retina), occurs less commonly and is often painless. Additional inflammatory conditions of the eye are summarized below:



Option Analysis

✅ Iris and ciliary body:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meibomian gland:
Incorrect: Chalazions result from the obstruction of Zeis or meibomian glands and present with lid discomfort and a non-tender nodule. An internal hordeolum is secondary to inflammation of the meibomian gland, resulting in swelling just under the conjunctival side of the eyelid. This patient’s presentation with a painful red eye, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Glands of Zeis and Moll:
Incorrect: External hordeola arise from glands in the eyelash follicle or lid-margin (gland of Zeis and gland of Moll). Patients typically present with localized, painful, and erythematous swelling of the eyelid.
❌ Conjunctiva and cornea:
Incorrect: Keratoconjunctivitis refers to inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva. Isolated corneal involvement is called keratitis, whereas conjunctival involvement is called conjunctivitis. This patient’s presentation with a painful red eye, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Choroid and retina:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the choroid and retina is called chorioretinitis, also known as posterior uveitis. This condition is usually painless and presents nonspecific visual changes, including floaters and reduced visual acuities. Redness of the eye is not a prominent feature of posterior inflammation without accompanying anterior uveitis.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset, painless vision loss of the left eye. He describes his left visual field suddenly appearing “black.” Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and a transient ischemic attack. The patient has a 40 pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 154/94 mmHg. Auscultation demonstrates a left-sided neck bruit. Cranial nerves III-XII are intact. The patient cannot see out of the left eye but has 20/20 vision in the right eye. The remainder of the exam, including strength, sensation, and gait, is unremarkable. Fundoscopy is performed as seen below.  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

CT angiography of the head and neck is pending. This patient most likely has occlusion of which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset, painless monocular vision loss, a carotid bruit, and a cherry-red spot on the macula, suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).  

CRAO typically presents painless, monocular vision loss and a pale retina with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. These findings occur secondary to loss of perfusion of the retina, allowing for blood from the choroid to become apparent. In elderly patients, embolic events secondary to ruptured internal carotid artery atherosclerosis are the most common cause of CRAO. The retinal artery serves as a branch of the ophthalmic artery, receiving blood from the internal carotid artery. The retinal artery supplies the inner retina and the surface of the optic nerve as it travels along with the retinal nerve. Terminal branches of the central retinal artery serve as end arteries, meaning that a proximal occlusion causes ischemia resulting in complete vision loss. Distal occlusions can lead to segmental retinal ischemia and partial vision loss.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the circle of Willis that supplies blood to the midline portions of the frontal and superior-medial parietal lobes. Occlusion of this artery can lead to loss of sensation and strength in the contralateral lower extremity, incontinence, and transcortical motor aphasia.
❌ Posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery leads to ischemic injury to the ipsilateral striate cortex, producing contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. Sudden painless total loss of vision is not observed with ischemic injury to this vessel.
✅ Central retinal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Branch retinal artery:
Incorrect: Branch retinal artery occlusion presents with sudden onset of visual field defects (scotomas) in the affected eye. Fundoscopy may demonstrate grayish-white discoloration of the retinal quadrant supplied by the affected vessel (in contrast to the entire retinal whitening with cherry-red spots seen in this patient).
❌ Central retinal vein:
Incorrect: Blockage of the central or branch retinal vein may occur due to compression from nearby arterial atherosclerosis. Fundoscopy often reveals a few dot-and-blot and flame-shaped hemorrhages in all four retinal quadrants. Retinal whitening with cherry-red spots instead suggests central retinal artery occlusion.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of visual problems in his right eye for the last six months. The patient tells the physician that he finds it difficult to see with his right eye because the eyelid is covering part of his vision. He is also experiencing double vision. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. On physical examination, the right eye is pointing down and out, and the right pupil is 9 mm. The right eyelid is drooping. Visual field examination is unremarkable except for diplopia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a “down and out” right eye and associated ptosis, mydriasis, and diplopia; he most likely has an oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy.

CN III has parasympathetic and somatic components. The former component supplies the ciliary muscles, which alter the shape of the lens to allow better focus on near objects, and the sphincter pupillae muscle, which constricts the pupil (miosis). Meanwhile, the inner somatic fibers provide nerve supply to the levator palpebrae superioris, which elevates the eyelid, and four of the extraocular muscles (superior, middle, inferior recti, and inferior oblique). These muscles are responsible for adjusting the gaze superiorly, medially, and inferiorly.  A helpful way to remember the anatomy of the parasympathetic and somatic fibers in CN III is the alliteration that the Parasympathetic fibers are Peripheral.

Clinical findings of CN III palsy depend on the components that are affected by the pathology. Loss of parasympathetic function leads to mydriasis and inability to accommodate to near objects, while loss of somatic function causes ptosis and deviation of the eye down and out (due to unopposed action of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles, which are innervated by CNs IV and VI, respectively).

Isolated CN III palsy is most commonly due to ischemia or compression. Ischemia is mostly caused by hypertension or diabetes mellitus and preferentially affects somatic fibers. Meanwhile, compression of CN III (e.g., by posterior communicating artery aneurysm, tentorial herniation) can lead to parasympathetic loss of function. However, it is not uncommon to see involvement of both the components.



Other possible causes of CN III palsy include injury to the CN III nucleus in the brainstem (e.g. demyelination), supranuclear injuries (e.g. injuries in the cerebral cortex), or injury in the cavernous sinus, where the CN III passes (along with other nerves and vascular structures). 

Option Analysis

✅ CN III (oculomotor) palsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CN IV (trochlear) palsy :
Incorrect: Patients with CN IV (trochlear) palsy present with vertical diplopia that worsens when reading or going downstairs. CN IV palsy is not associated with ptosis or mydriasis.
❌ CN VI (abducens) palsy:
Incorrect: CN VI palsy is not associated with ptosis or mydriasis, and in CN VI palsy, the eye is deviated medially. 
❌ Horner syndrome :
Incorrect: Although Horner syndrome does present with ptosis, it is associated with miosis, not mydriasis. Also, diplopia is not expected in Horner syndrome. 
❌ CN VII (facial) palsy :
Incorrect: Facial nerve palsy is associated with loss of motor function in the muscles of the face. The facial nerve does not provide parasympathetic innervation to the eye (mydriasis), nor does it innervate the extraocular muscles.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left eye pain and swelling for three hours. He was brought in by local police following an altercation at a bar, where he was punched in the left eye. He reports that he has double vision when looking upward. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg. On examination, the left orbit is ecchymotic with associated swelling. Pupils are equal and reactive to light, and visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Neurologic evaluation demonstrates diminished sensation of the skin to fine touch at the left lower eyelid and left anterior cheek. A CT scan of the face reveals a fracture of the floor of the left orbit with entrapment of orbital contents in the left maxillary sinus. Injury to which of the following nerves is the most likely etiology of this patient’s sensory deficits?
questions.solution:
Orbital fractures occur when one or more of the fragile bones composing the orbit break. They are classified into several types including orbital rim fractures, orbital roof fractures, and orbital floor fractures, which are also known as blowout fractures. Patients with orbital floor fractures almost always have a history of blunt trauma to the orbit (e.g., assault, motor vehicle accident, sports-related trauma).  

Symptoms of an orbital floor fracture include unilateral periorbital pain, edema and ecchymoses, enophthalmos (a posterior displacement of the eyeball), or proptosis (anterior displacement of the eyeball). If eye movement is restricted due to entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle, diplopia and pain may occur during eye movements. An entrapped inferior rectus keeps the affected eye in a downward position, leading to diplopia with attempted upward gaze. In severe fractures, the infraorbital or supraorbital nerves can be involved, resulting in numbness below the eye or forehead respectively. Injury to the infraorbital nerve results in decreased sensation along the cheek, upper lip, and upper gingiva.


Left orbital floor fracture  
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

Option Analysis

✅ Infraorbital nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Buccal nerve:
Incorrect: The buccal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve that transmits sensory information from skin over the buccal membrane and from the second and third molars.
❌ Supraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: The supraorbital nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin of the lateral forehead and upper eyelid, as well as the conjunctiva of the upper eyelid and mucosa of the frontal sinus.
❌ Supratrochlear nerve:
Incorrect: The supratrochlear nerve is a branch of the frontal nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the skin of the forehead and upper eyelid.
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve is a branch of the maxillary nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the skin over the zygomatic and temporal bones.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician with diplopia. The patient tells the physician that he has fallen multiple times because of having double vision. The problem started eight months ago, and it has not improved. Past medical history of the patient includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. On physical examination, the left eye is pointing downwards and outwards. Both pupils are 4 mm in diameter, and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Ischemic injury of the oculomotor nerve
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery
Compression of CN III by the uncus of the temporal lobe

questions.solution:
This patient with diplopia and a “down and out” right eye most likely has damage to the somatic component of the oculomotor nerve (CN III). Ischemia, secondary to diabetes and hypertensive vasculopathy, is the most common cause.

CN III has parasympathetic and somatic components. The former is present in the outer region of the nerve, while the latter is found in the center of the nerve. A helpful way to remember this distinction is the alliteration that the Parasympathetic fibers are Peripheral. Clinical findings of CN III palsy depend on the components that are affected by the pathology. Loss of parasympathetic function leads to mydriasis and inability to accommodate to near objects, while loss of the somatic function causes ptosis and deviation of the eye down and out (due to unopposed action of superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles, innervated by CN IV and VI, respectively).

Isolated CN III palsy is most commonly due to ischemia or compression. Ischemia is mostly caused by hypertension or diabetes mellitus and preferentially affects somatic fibers. Compression of CN III (e.g., by posterior communicating artery aneurysm, tentorial herniation) can lead to parasympathetic loss of function. However, it is not uncommon to see involvement of both the components.



Option Analysis

✅ Ischemic injury of the oculomotor nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Posterior communicating artery aneurysms are one of the most common causes of CN III injury. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery is another cause of CN III injury. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery is also a cause of compression injury of CN III. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of CN III by the uncus of the temporal lobe:
Incorrect: Uncal herniation through the tentorium cerebelli can compress CN III. However, this is an emergency, and patients will present with other neurological manifestations (e.g., coma, spastic paresis). Moreover, compression injuries to CN III affect the parasympathetic fibers, leading to dilated, nonreactive pupils.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man comes to the emergency department to evaluate severe left eye pain and loss of vision that started one hour ago. He has vomited twice. The patient takes hydrochlorothiazide and tamsulosin for hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Ophthalmic examination demonstrates left conjunctival injection and a hazy cornea. The right eye is grossly normal. Left intraocular pressure is measured at 24 mmHg (normal range 8-21 mmHg).



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following anatomical structures is the primary site of pathology in this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset vision loss, eye pain, and increased intraocular pressure consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma. Glaucoma is a group of ocular diseases that damage the optic nerve secondary to increased intraocular pressure. The two primary types include open-angle glaucoma and closed-angle glaucoma.

Angle-closure glaucoma occurs when the iris bulges forward to narrow or block the drainage angle formed by the cornea and iris, termed the iridocorneal angle. As a result, fluid cannot circulate through the anterior chamber, which results in increased intraocular pressure.

In open-angle glaucoma, the drainage angle formed by the cornea and iris remains open, but the trabecular meshwork is partially blocked. This results in pressure in the eye gradually increasing, resulting in progressive damage to the optic nerve.

Without treatment, both conditions can result in complete blindness.  

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior chamber:
Incorrect: The posterior chamber is a narrow space behind the iris and in front of the suspensory ligament of the lens and ciliary processes. This structure is not implicated in patients with acute angle-closure glaucoma.
❌ Anterior chamber:
Incorrect: The anterior chamber is the fluid-filled space between the iris and the corneal endothelium. Aqueous humor fills the anterior chamber and flows to the trabecular meshwork. The anterior chamber itself is not involved in acute angle-closure glaucoma.
✅ Iridocorneal angle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ciliary body:
Incorrect: The ciliary body is the part of the eye that includes the ciliary muscle and ciliary epithelium. The ciliary body comprises a part of the uvea, the layer of tissue that delivers oxygen and nutrients to ocular tissue.
❌ Vitreous humor:
Incorrect: Vitreous humor is a transparent, colorless, gelatinous mass that fills the space between the lens and the retina.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent pain in his lower extremities and back for the past two months. He describes these episodes as sudden, brief, severe stabs of pain that affect his legs and back, lasting for minutes to hours. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II. He had a sexually transmitted infection in his teenage years, but he cannot remember what it was, and it resolved without treatment. He takes metformin, and he is inconsistent with clinic follow-ups. Physical examination of the lower extremities shows absence of deep tendon reflexes and impaired vibratory sensation and two-point discrimination, with normal motor strength. The Romberg test is positive. On ophthalmologic examination, the pupils fail to constrict in response to direct light, but when the patient is asked to focus on the examiner's index finger, the pupils constrict uniformly. CSF analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis. Which part of the pupillary light reflex pathway is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s pupils are nonreactive to light with the retained ability to accommodate; this finding is consistent with Argyll Robertson (AR) pupil, most likely secondary to tabes dorsalis (tertiary syphilis) given the noted history of an untreated sexually transmitted infection. He also has the characteristic lancinating pains, physical examination findings of impaired vibratory sense, positive Romberg test, and absent deep tendon reflexes, in addition to CSF findings of lymphocytic pleocytosis, all of which are seen in tertiary syphilis.

The pupillary light and accommodation reflexes start at the retina, where sensory information travels through the optic tract. For the pupillary accommodation reflex, information goes to the lateral geniculate body, then into the visual cortex, then to the superior colliculus, before arriving at the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. For the pupillary light reflex, sensory information travels straight from the optic tract into the pretectal nucleus and then to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.

Based on these two different pathways, we can see three possible sites of a lesion which may result in preservation of the accommodation reflex but loss of the pupillary light reflex. First, there may be a lesion along the pathway from the optic tract to the midbrain only affecting the pupillary light pathway fibers; second, there may be a lesion of the pretectal nuclei where only the pupillary light reflex synapses; and third, there may be damage to the part of the Edinger-Westphal nuclei that receives input only from the pretectal nuclei, not the superior colliculus fibers of the accommodation reflex. It is thought that neurosyphilis affects one of these areas, resulting in an AR pupil.

The AR pupils don’t constrict in response to light but are responsive to accommodation (when focused on a nearby object). AR pupils are highly suggestive of tertiary syphilis; however, they can occur in other underlying conditions, such as diabetes and multiple sclerosis.



Option Analysis

✅ Edinger-Westphal nucleus.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ciliary ganglion:
Incorrect: Damage to the ciliary ganglion will cause Holmes-Adie Syndrome, in which the pupils are dilated and react slowly to direct light.
❌ Optic nerve:
Incorrect: Damage or inflammation to the optic nerve (e.g. optic neuritis) causes pain with eye movements or at rest, as well as loss of vision.
❌ Superior colliculus:
Incorrect: Superior colliculus is not involved in the pupillary light reflex pathway. It is a part of the pupillary accommodation reflex pathway, which is intact in this patient.
❌ Short ciliary nerve:
Incorrect: Damage to the short ciliary nerve will lead to loss of the pupillary reflex and mydriasis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician with double vision, which started three weeks ago. She noticed that her double vision worsens when she is reading. She also has had difficulty walking downstairs. On physical examination, the patient prefers to keep her head tilted towards the right side. Ophthalmologic examination is significant for deviation of the left eye outward and upwards. Both pupils are 3 mm in diameter and are reactive to light. The physician suspects a cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following ocular muscles most likely lost innervation due to the cranial nerve palsy seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is a pure motor nerve that is responsible for innervating the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for internal rotation of the eye; it is the main muscle that depresses the eye when it is adducted.



CN IV palsy results in the loss of the superior oblique muscle action. The patient usually complains of vertical diplopia, which is mostly seen when looking inward and downwards (e.g., reading a book, descending the stairs). In addition, due to the loss of internal rotation, the eye rests in the “out and up” position. This causes the patient to tilt their head toward the contralateral side in order to minimize the diplopia.



Isolated CN IV palsy is rare and is most commonly idiopathic, which is thought to be congenital and usually appears in the fourth decade of life. Other risk factors include head trauma and diabetes. 

Option Analysis

✅ The superior oblique muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The inferior oblique muscle:
Incorrect: The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The medial rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The medial rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The inferior rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The inferior rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The lateral rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the abducens nerve. Abducens nerve palsy results in eye deviation medially, with inability to look laterally, and nystagmus on lateral gaze.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 1-day history of pain and swelling of his right eye. The patient does not have any visual changes or a history of trauma. The parents report the patient was in contact with a child at daycare who recently had an upper respiratory tract infection. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates localized swelling along the right lower margin of the eyelid with associated erythema and tenderness. A photograph of the right eye is shown. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Involvement of which of the following structures is implicated in this patient’s current ocular complaint?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a hordeolum (stye), an abscess of the eyelid. External hordeolum arises from glands in the eyelash follicle or lid-margin (gland of Zeis and gland of Moll), whereas internal hordeolum is caused by inflammation of the meibomian gland. The infection is most commonly due to Staphylococcus aureus, but the hordeola can be sterile.

Chalazion, another condition of the eyelid, results from the obstruction of Zeis or meibomian glands. It typically presents with painless localized eyelid swelling and a nontender rubbery nodule on examination (see image below).



Reproduce fromWikimedia Commons

Differences between hordeolum and chalazion are summarized below:



Option Analysis

✅ Zeis/Moll glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meibomian gland:
Incorrect: Chalazions result from obstruction of the Zeis or meibomian glands. This condition presents with lid discomfort and a painless nodule under the conjunctival eyelid. This patient instead has a tender nodule at the lid margin.
❌ Lacrimal sac:
Incorrect: Dacrocystitis refers to infection of the lacrimal sac and is characterized by pain and redness of the medial canthus. This patient has a tender nodule at the lid margin.
❌ Cornea:
Incorrect: The cornea serves as the site of infection in viral keratitis from herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. Patients present with corneal vesicles, as well as opacification and dendritic ulcers.
❌ Episcleral tissue:
Incorrect: Episcleritis refers to the infection or inflammation of the episcleral tissue between the conjunctiva and sclera. Patients endorse acute onset mild to moderate discomfort, photophobia, and watery discharge, and examination reveals diffuse bulbar conjunctival injection.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of double vision and headache, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Her symptoms started three days ago and have worsened since the onset. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Ophthalmologic examination reveals bilateral papilledema and medial deviation of the right eye. Abduction of the right eye is impaired. All other eye movements are normal in both the eyes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s double vision?

choices.text: Compression of a cranial nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery
Stretching and injury to a cranial nerve over the petrous portion of the temporal bone
Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery
Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.solution:
This patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) including papilledema, nausea, vomiting and headache. The ophthalmologic findings of diplopia and dysfunction of lateral gaze of the right eye are concerning for abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy. This patient most likely has a space-occupying lesion that is stretching and injuring the CN VI for which imaging (e.g. MRI) is warranted.

The abducens nerve (CN VI) is a pure motor nerve that supplies the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abducting the eye. It exits the midbrain at the level of pontomedullary junction, then crosses over the petrous apex of the temporal bone, where it enters the cavernous sinus. It then travels towards the lateral rectus muscle.

CN VI palsy causes loss of lateral movement of the affected eye, leaving the action of the medial rectus muscle unopposed, which leads to medial deviation of the eye and resulting diplopia. Diplopia usually worsens when looking towards the side of the lesion and resolves when looking away from the lesion.



The most common cause of abducens nerve palsy is increased ICP, which can stretch the nerve as it crosses over the petrous apex. Common causes of increased ICP include space-occupying lesions (e.g., tumor, abscess). Other causes of CN VI palsy include head trauma, cavernous sinus thrombosis, demyelinating disorders, ischemic vascular disease and mastoiditis or otitis media, which may spread to the petrous portion of the temporal bone and damage the abducens nerve.



Option Analysis

❌ Compression of a cranial nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery can compress the oculomotor nerve. This causes the eye to deviate down and out and the affected pupil to dilate (mydriasis). None of this is seen in this patient. Instead, this patient is most likely having CN VI palsy due to increased intracranial pressure.
✅ Stretching and injury to a cranial nerve over the petrous portion of the temporal bone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus:
Incorrect: Cavernous sinus thrombosis can cause CN VI palsy, but this condition is usually associated with proptosis, orbital swelling, and other cranial nerve palsies (e.g., CN III, CN IV).
❌ Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The posterior cerebral artery supplies the medial midbrain. Its occlusion causes Weber syndrome, which is characterized by oculomotor nerve dysfunction with associated contralateral hemiparesis, which are not seen in this patient.
❌ Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), which is characterized by loss of the gag reflex, dysphagia, hoarseness, and loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face and the contralateral side of the body. This patient does not have Wallenberg syndrome.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man comes to the office because of tearing and blurry vision in the right eye. The patient also reports progressive headaches and says that “I feel like the right side of my face has been getting heavier.” The patient has had no fever, runny nose, sore throat, or cough. He does not report any trauma or loss of consciousness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus that are both well-controlled with medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right nasolabial fold flattening and drooping of the right lower lip. The patient is unable to close the right eye. The left side of the face appears normal. The ocular examination is shown below.  


Reproduced from wikipedia

MRI of the brain reveals a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing posterior fossa mass compressing the right facial nerve root. Impairment of which of the following facial muscles is most likely responsible for this patient’s ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with right facial paralysis and an inability to close the right eye,  consistent with facial (CN VII) nerve palsy, likely due to compression from a meningioma in the posterior fossa.

A portion of the facial (VII) motor nucleus innervates the orbicularis oculi, closing the eyelids and wrinkling the forehead. The orbicularis oculi have three components:  

  •  Palpebral part: gently closes the eyelids (as in blinking or sleep) to keep the cornea moist 
  •  Lacrimal part: draws the eyelids medially, aiding in drainage of tears 
  • Orbital part: tightly closes the eyelids (as in winking or squinting) to protect the eyes from glare and dust.

Paralysis of the facial nerve results in loss of tone of the orbicularis oculi, resulting in the inferior eyelid eversion (or falling away from the surface of the eyeball). As a result, lacrimal fluid does not spread to the cornea, preventing adequate lubrication, hydration, and flushing. Corneal reflexes are also lost due to impaired blinking, resulting in further drying of the cornea, eventually leading to corneal ulceration (demonstrated in the photo above).  

Option Analysis

❌ Orbicularis oris:
Incorrect: The orbicularis oris closes the oral fissure and causes a phasic contraction to protrude the lips (kissing) and resist distension (when blowing). Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye.
✅ Orbicularis oculi:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Occipitofrontalis:
Incorrect: The occipitofrontalis elevates the eyebrows and wrinkles the skin of the forehead. Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye. 
❌ Corrugator supercilii:
Incorrect: The corrugator supercilii is a facial muscle that draws the eyebrow medially inferiorly, creating vertical wrinkles above the nose (demonstrating concern or worry). Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye. 
❌ Risorius:
Incorrect: The risorius depresses the labial commissures to frown (expressing sadness). Although the facial nerve also innervates this muscle, it does not close the eye.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of a one-week history of eye pain and double vision. The patient also noticed swelling that started around her right eye but is now around both eyes. She says she feels “warm” but does not have a thermometer at home to take her temperature. Before her symptoms started, she had a toothache, for which she tried ibuprofen. She did not see a dentist. She has no significant past medical or surgical history. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals proptosis of both eyes with periorbital edema. In addition, abduction of the right eye is impaired. All other eye movements are normal, and both pupils are 3 mm in diameter and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ophthalmalgia, periorbital edema that started unilaterally and quickly progressed bilaterally, and CN VI palsy; she most likely has cavernous sinus syndrome. She also has high-grade fever in the setting of a possible tooth infection, making cavernous sinus thrombosis the most likely cause.

The cavernous sinus is a dural venous sinus that is found lateral to the sella turcica on both sides. It contains many important structures including the abducens nerve (CN VI), the internal carotid artery and associated postganglionic sympathetic fibers, the oculomotor nerve (CN III), the trochlear nerve (CN IV), and the ophthalmic (V1) and maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V)



The abducens nerve and internal carotid artery (with its postganglionic sympathetic fibers) run in the center of the sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic and maxillary nerves run along the lateral walls of the sinus. As a result, abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy is the first and most common palsy associated with cavernous sinus syndrome, though other structures in the sinus can also be affected.

In addition to nerve palsies, patients usually develop headache, periorbital edema, proptosis, and chemosis, which start unilaterally and then progress to bilateral involvement. Horner syndrome can occur with injury to the postganglionic fibers. Fever can be present if the cause is septic, and patients can develop vision loss.

Cavernous sinus syndrome can occur due to tumors (e.g., meningioma, pituitary tumor), carotid artery aneurysm, and cavernous sinus thrombosis. Cavernous sinus thrombosis usually occurs due to an infection spreading from adjacent structures such as sinuses, ears, eyes, or teeth.




Option Analysis

✅ Cavernous sinus thrombosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension:
Incorrect: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) presents with headache, nausea, vomiting, and decreased visual acuity. It is not associated with fever, proptosis, or periorbital edema.
❌ Orbital cellulitis:
Incorrect: Orbital cellulitis can cause proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and fever. However, it is exceedingly rare to be bilateral. The bilateral nature of this patient’s symptoms favors cavernous sinus thrombosis as the diagnosis.
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Although multiple sclerosis can cause demyelination of any cranial nerve (including the abducens nerve), it is not associated with acute proptosis or orbital swelling. In addition, this patient does not have a history of other neurological manifestations disseminated in place and time (e.g., lower extremity paresis, ataxia).
❌ Superior vena cava syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior vena cava syndrome is characterized by diffuse facial and neck swelling and plethora, distended neck veins, upper extremities swelling, cough, and dyspnea. This patient has orbital swelling with ophthalmoplegia, making cavernous sinus syndrome more likely.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to his primary care physician to evaluate right-sided vision changes over six months. The patient also has noted an increase in swelling in his right upper arm.  Past medical history is significant for myocardial infarction and hyperlipidemia. The patient has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He has a droopy right eyelid and intact extraocular eye movements on examination. Pupils are asymmetric in dim light – 2 mm on the right and 4 mm on the left, with both reactive to light. The pupils become more symmetric in bright light. The skin on the right half of his face appears cracked and dry. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s right eye droop?

choices.text: Congenital abnormality of the levator muscle

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with Horner syndrome, likely due to a Pancoast tumor. The ptosis observed in Horner syndrome results from paralysis of the Müller muscle, innervated by the sympathetic pathway. Horner syndrome is characterized by ipsilateral:

  •  Partial ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid): due to the sympathetic denervation of the Müller muscle (superior tarsal muscle). 
  •  Miosis (constriction of the pupil): due to the interruption of sympathetic fibers to the iris dilator muscles, which leads to uncontrolled parasympathetic influence (leading to anisocoria and dilation lag on the exam).
  • Anhidrosis (absence of sweating): due to impaired sympathetic innervation to facial sweat glands.
Horner syndrome can result from a lesion on the three-neuron sympathetic (adrenergic) pathway. Neurons for this pathway originate in the hypothalamus (first-order neurons). Their axons descend caudally to the first synapse located in the cervical spinal cord (levels C8-T2, also called the ciliospinal center of Budge). Second-order neurons exit the spinal cord through the anterior nerve roots and synapse with third-order neurons located at the superior cervical ganglion. Here, the oculosympathetic pathway travels along the carotid arteries to join target tissues in the face and eyes.

Causes of Horner syndrome based on anatomic lesions and associated anatomical pathways are summarized below:



Option Analysis

❌ Paralysis of the orbicularis oculi:
Incorrect: The orbicularis oculi functions to close the eyelids and wrinkle the forehead vertically. It can be paralyzed in facial nerve palsy and usually manifests as inferior eyelid eversion, inadequate corneal lubrication, an inability of the eyelid to close, and loss of corneal reflexes. Partial right-sided ptosis suggests an alternate etiology.
✅ Paralysis of Müller's muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Complete third nerve palsy:
Incorrect: This patient’s extraocular eye movements are intact; therefore, a complete third nerve palsy is unlikely.
❌ Congenital abnormality of the levator muscle:
Incorrect: Congenital ptosis is often associated with absence or reduced function of the striated levator palpebrae superioris. This condition is typically unilateral, neurologically isolated, and nonprogressive. Lid creases are absent, and amblyopia and strabismus are often observed.
❌ Dehiscence of levator aponeurosis:
Incorrect: In adults, the most common cause of acquired ptosis is spontaneous disinsertion or dehiscence of the levator aponeurosis. Associated miosis and anhidrosis make this an unlikely cause of this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of a six month history of progressively worsening headaches. She has also noticed blurred peripheral vision while driving. The patient does not report any head trauma or associated dizziness, weight changes, diplopia, or polyuria. Past medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a bitemporal visual field defect. Laboratory studies reveal a prolactin level that is greater than 20 times normal and cranial imaging shows a large pituitary mass. Based on the diagram below, which of the following visual pathways is most likely disrupted in this patient?
questions.solution:
The optic tracts relay visual information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus, from where it continues to the occipital lobe and primary visual cortex. The x-shaped optic chiasm is the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure causes bitemporal hemianopsia. Common causes include pressure exerted by pituitary tumor (as seen in this patient), craniopharyngioma, as well as aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery.   

The aneurysm of the internal carotid artery can also laterally impinge on the optic chiasm and cause ipsilateral nasal hemianopia, damaging uncrossed optic nerve fibers from the temporal portion of the retina. Other visual field defects that may be seen with lesions at different points along the optic nerve pathway are summarized in the diagram below:  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: A partial lesion of the retina is more likely to produce a focal monocular scotoma rather than bitemporal visual field defect.  
❌ B:
Incorrect:: The optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the right CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (right anopsia) as well as a right relative afferent pupillary defect.  
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: Damage to the lateral aspect of the optic chiasm usually results from calcification or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery impinging on uncrossed lateral retinal fibers causing unilateral nasal hemianopia.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: The right optic tract transmits visual information from the left visual field and vice versa. A right optic tract lesion is likely to cause left homonymous hemianopsia rather than bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being struck with a baseball bat. The patient reports pain in the left eyebrow but does not have vision changes or pain with eye movements. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a hematoma and tenderness to palpation over the supraorbital rim. A CT scan of the face is shown below. Which of the following nerves is at risk of injury based on this patient’s traumatic mechanism?
   

Reproduced from: radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a supraorbital rim fracture after being struck with a blunt object. Given this mechanism and location of the injury, the supratrochlear nerve is at the highest risk of damage.

The trigeminal nerve branches into the frontal nerve within the orbit, dividing into the supraorbital nerve and supratrochlear nerve as they traverse via a bony recess called the supraorbital notch. These nerves provide sensory information to the skin of the forehead and scalp and are at risk of injury as they course superiorly from the orbit.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supratrochlear nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Infraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: The infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information to the lower portion of the orbit. This patient’s injury is at the superior aspect of the orbit.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s injury pattern.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This nerve is more likely to be damaged with injury to the lateral face.  
❌ Nasociliary nerve:
Incorrect: The nasociliary nerve, a branch of V1, is less likely to be implicated given this patient’s injury due to its course within the orbit. This patient does not have evidence of damage to orbital structures.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of throbbing headaches for three weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and an episode of double vision lasting minutes. The patient has been taking over-the-counter analgesics with only mild improvement in her symptoms. Past medical history is significant for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Current medications include metformin and isotretinoin. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision field testing. Fundoscopic findings of the left eye are demonstrated below, with similar findings in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the observed fundoscopic findings in this patient?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), which typically presents in young obese females with daily headaches, bilateral symmetric papilledema, and transient visual disturbance. The fundoscopic findings of optic disc swelling (elevation of the optic disc with blurred disc margins) are suggestive of papilledema.  

Papilledema is a term exclusively used to describe optic disc swelling, secondary to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The optic nerve is surrounded by subarachnoid space containing cerebrospinal fluid, so any condition that raises ICP will compress this nerve. Prolonged compression also occludes the central retinal vein, resulting in venous engorgement and peripapillary hemorrhage. Additional conditions that can manifest with papilledema include central nervous system infections or tumors.   

Option Analysis

❌ Macular degeneration:
Incorrect: Degeneration of the macula can be observed in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is subdivided into dry and wet AMD. This condition results in the gradual loss of central vision and metamorphopsia in affected eyes.   
✅ Elevated intracranial pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired retinal perfusion:
Incorrect: Impaired retinal perfusion occurs with central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO), often secondary to cardiac emboli in young patients and carotid atherosclerosis in geriatric patients. CRAO presents with acute painless visual loss in the affected eye.   
❌ Elevated intraocular pressure:
Incorrect: An acute elevation intraocular pressure is characteristic of acute-angle closure glaucoma, which typically presents with painful monocular vision loss, headache, vomiting, conjunctival injection, and a mid-dilated non-reactive pupil.  
❌ Middle cerebral artery embolism:
Incorrect: Embolic occlusion of the middle cerebral artery can lead to the development of contralateral homonymous hemianopia. However, owing to the extensive area of the brain that the MCA supplies, other signs of stroke, such as contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss, would also be apparent.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office because of a two week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and worsening headache. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient recently recovered from bacterial pneumonia two months ago. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the last thirty-eight years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic small cell cancer of the lung is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown below. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
The visual pathway transmits visual information from the retina to the visual cortex through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations. The superior bundle of right optic radiations (right dorsal optic radiation) relays information from the left inferior quadrants of the visual field (i.e. from the right superior quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right superior bundle of optic radiations would produce left lower homonymous quadrantanopia (“pie on the floor”).    

Other visual field defects that may be seen with lesions at different points along the optic nerve pathway are summarized in the diagram below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Right macula:
Incorrect: The right macula transmits visual information from the center of the right eye's visual field. Damage to the right macula (e.g. due to macular degeneration) results in right central scotoma.   
❌ Optic chiasm:
Incorrect: The optic chiasm is where the optic nerve fibers of the nasal side of the retina cross the midline. Damage to this structure would result in bitemporal hemianopsia.   
❌ Right optic tract:
Incorrect: The right optic tract transmits information from the left half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the nasal half of the left retina and temporal half of the right retina). Damage to the right optic tract would result in left homonymous hemianopsia.   
❌ Right Meyer loop:
Incorrect: The inferior bundle of right optic radiations (right Meyer loop) is located in the right temporal lobe and transmits visual information from the left superior quadrants of the visual field (i.e. from the right lower quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right Meyer loop would result in left upper homonymous quadrantanopia (“pie in the sky”).  
✅ Right dorsal optic radiation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being involved in a fight at a bar. The patient was punched in his left eye and reports double vision when looking upward. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates periorbital swelling and ecchymosis and an inability of the left eye to gaze upward. A CT of the face is shown below. Which of the following neurologic deficits is expected on further physical examination?
   

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

choices.text: Diminished sensation over the left lower eyelid
Jaw deviation to the left with the opening of the mouth
Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp
Diminished sensation along the left mandible

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of an orbital floor fracture, including inferior rectus muscle entrapment (diplopia and limited upward gaze). Orbital floor fractures are commonly associated with injuries to the infraorbital nerve, given its course along the inferior aspect of the orbit. Maxillary sinus surgeries also place this nerve at high risk of injury.

The infraorbital nerve is a branch of V2 of the trigeminal nerve and supplies sensation to the skin of the lower eyelid, side of the nose, anteroinferior nasal septum, cheek, and upper lip. Damage to this nerve often manifests sensory deficits in these areas. Thus, maxillary sinus infections and sinusitis often result in pain in the upper teeth.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diminished sensation over the left lower eyelid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Jaw deviation to the left with the opening of the mouth:
Incorrect: Jaw deviation to the left with the opening of the mouth would be expected with complete injury to the V3 branch of the trigeminal nerve or injury to the nerve root/ganglion. Orbital floor fractures are unlikely to damage the entirety of V3.  
❌ Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp may occur with injury to the frontal nerve or its branches. This is more likely to occur with supraorbital rim fractures, not orbital floor fractures.  
❌ Diminished sensation along the left mandible:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation along the left mandible would reflect injury to the inferior alveolar nerve, which is more commonly injured during lower molar extractions--not orbital floor fractures.  
❌ Left eye blindness:
Incorrect: Left eye blindness may occur with damage to cranial nerve I. Significant damage to this nerve is unlikely with orbital floor fractures.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate rash and right eye pain. The patient states she first noticed a rash over her right forehead five days ago, and it has become more painful over time. The patient says she began having worsening pain in her right eye today with associated light sensitivity and redness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the findings demonstrated in the image below. Which of the following nerves is implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with vesicular lesions over the forehead, eye, and nose--with evidence of corneal involvement--consistent with herpes zoster ophthalmicus. The pathogenesis of this disease begins with reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in the trigeminal nerve ganglion, which subsequently results in lesions in distribution following the ophthalmic nerve (V1 distribution of the trigeminal nerve).

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus, a potentially sight-threatening condition, typically presents with vesicular lesions in distribution following V1--over the forehead and scalp (frontal nerve), nose (nasociliary nerve), or eye that eventually involve the cornea and associated eye structures. Patients often endorse a prodrome of headache and low-grade fevers, followed by pain and eruption of a vesicular rash. Associated signs include the Hutchinson sign--which refers to cutaneous involvement of the tip of the nose, indicating nasociliary nerve involvement. Vesicular lesions in this distribution carry a high risk of ocular involvement. Without treatment with antiviral agents (acyclovir, valacyclovir), lesions may progress to erode ocular structures, resulting in blindness.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ophthalmic nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Maxillary nerve:
Incorrect: The maxillary nerve (V2) is not often implicated in the pathogenesis of herpes zoster ophthalmicus. This nerve provides sensation to the area over the maxilla, nasal cavity, sinuses, palate, and mid-face.  
❌ Mandibular nerve:
Incorrect: The mandibular nerve (V3), another branch of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.  
❌ Optic nerve:
Incorrect: The optic nerve, or CNI, provides sensory information to the brain regarding sight. This nerve can become involved in the late stages of herpes zoster ophthalmicus, resulting in total blindness.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of difficulty seeing out of her left eye. The patient began having painful eye movements and blurry vision two days ago and recalls two similar episodes that self-resolved several years ago. Each episode was associated with deficits in color vision. The patient does not have any recent trauma, loss of consciousness, or speech changes. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination demonstrates left optic disc atrophy and a relative afferent pupillary defect. There is impaired adduction of the right eye with left lateral gaze. Convergence shows normal adduction of both eyes. MRI of the brain demonstrates abnormal enhancement of the left optic nerve. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of preferential involvement of the optic nerve in this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges
Antibody binding at the neuromuscular junction

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of optic neuritis and multiple sclerosis–an immune-mediated demyelinating disease, thought to result from immune-mediated damage to myelin basic proteins (oligodendrocytes) via Th1 cells.    

In the optic nerve, myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes and may be affected in demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis. This is not true for other cranial nerves in which myelin is created by Schwann cells. Acute demyelinating injury to the optic nerve causes optic neuritis, which commonly present with vision loss and eye pain.   

The relative afferent pupillary defect (aka Marcus Gunn pupil) results from an impaired direct pupillary reflex in the affected eye and indirect pupillary reflex in the normal eye. It can be tested via the swinging flashlight test.  

  •  While the patient fixates on a point in the distance, swing a light back and forth from one eye to the other and observe the size of the pupils. 
  •  Normally, both the illuminated pupil and the non illuminated pupil constrict. 
  •  If the optic nerve of one eye is damaged, both pupils will dilate when light shines in the affected eye. 


Option Analysis

✅ Destruction of oligodendrocytes by T-cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osmotically-mediated Schwann cell damage:
Incorrect: Osmotically-mediated Schwann cell damage is observed in diabetic neuropathy due to chronic hyperglycemia. Diabetic neuropathy presents with a stocking-glove distribution and is associated with dysesthesias and loss of sensation. The optic nerve is sheathed by the myelin of oligodendrocytes (not schwann cells).  
❌ Lymphocytic infiltrate of the endoneurium:
Incorrect: Lymphocytic infiltrate of the endoneurium is observed with Guillain-Barré syndrome. This syndrome manifests with polyneuropathy and ascending flaccid paralysis following a bacterial or viral infection .  
❌ Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges:
Incorrect: Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges is characteristic of aseptic meningitis, secondary to late-stage Lyme disease (neuroborreliosis). This patient has no history of a tick bite or erythema migrans to suggest Lyme disease.  
❌ Antibody binding at the neuromuscular junction:
Incorrect: The pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis involves binding of antibodies to postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors, resulting in impaired neuromuscular transmission. Although this patient has visual changes often seen in patients with myasthenia gravis, they do not present with ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician's office for evaluation of anxiety, weight loss and blurry vision. The patient has been feeling irritable and “on edge” at work for months, and she has lost 13-lb over this same time period, despite maintaining her diet. The patient states that her eyes have been feeling “uncomfortable,” reporting excessive tearing and episodic double vision. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 142/94 mmHg. The patient appears anxious. Ocular examination reveals bilateral proptosis, excessive tearing, and periorbital edema. When the physician asks the patient to follow his finger as he moves it superiorly and inferiorly, the patient’s sclera can be observed above the iris when the patient's eyes track downward. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated free T3 and T4 level with an undetectable level of TSH. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s ocular findings?

choices.text: Hormonal secretion from an underlying malignancy
Infection posterior to the orbital septum

questions.solution:
Graves ophthalmopathy refers to the ocular manifestation of Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder resulting in autoantibodies, specifically thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSH-receptor antibodies), that can also activate the T-cells in the retro-orbital space. This activation results in secretion of cytokines such as TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma, increasing fibroblast secretion of glycosaminoglycans, causing ocular muscle swelling, inflammation, and an increase in the number of adipocytes. Ultimately, this manifests as exophthalmos, an anterior bulging of the eyes. In addition, lid lag may also be observed, where sclera can be seen above the iris as the patient looks down due to the increased sympathetic stimulation of the levator palpebrae superioris and superior tarsal muscles.  

Diagnosis is confirmed by histology of the thyroid, which will demonstrate tall and crowded follicular epithelial cells with scalloped colloid. Treatment of Graves ophthalmopathy includes glucocorticoids due to their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties. Treatment of Graves disease itself involves antithyroid agents, such as propylthiouracil or methimazole.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retro-orbital fibroblast secretion of glycosaminoglycans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hormonal secretion from an underlying malignancy:
Incorrect: Paraneoplastic syndrome from an underlying malignancy can result in hormonal derangements. Paraneoplastic syndromes affecting the eyes include Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) and dermatomyositis. This patient’s exophthalmos and clinical presentation are instead indicative of Graves disease.
❌ Autoantibodies binding postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis (MG) is characterized by autoantibodies that bind postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors, inducing muscle weakness. Ocular manifestations of MG include weakness of the eyelid muscles, resulting in ptosis.
❌ Autoantibodies binding presynaptic calcium channels:
Incorrect: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a neuromuscular junction disorder resulting in muscle weakness. Ocular manifestations of LEMS include ptosis and diplopia, although most patients present with autonomic dysfunction (e.g. dry mouth, sluggish pupils, erectile dysfunction). 
❌ Infection posterior to the orbital septum:
Correct: Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the connective tissue of the orbit, mostly the fat and ocular muscles. Symptoms include pain with eye movements, proptosis or bulging of the eyeball, redness and swelling of the eyelid, and in some cases, ophthalmoplegia or impairment of eye movement. These are often accompanied by systemic symptoms, such as fever and chills, which are absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of dull left eye pain, which developed four days ago. He has also experienced photophobia and conjunctival injection but no visual disturbances. Past medical history is notable for ankylosing spondylitis and Crohn disease, for which he is taking infliximab. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for an intraocular pressure of 17 mmHg in the right eye and 35 mmHg in the left eye. In addition, ciliary flush and keratic precipitates are noted on slit-lamp examination of the left eye. Bilateral pupils are reactive to light. Examination of the left retina reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?

choices.text: Separation of retina from underlying support tissue

questions.solution:
This patient has an elevated intraocular pressure and optic nerve cupping. In addition, he has a history of autoimmune conditions, as well as the presence of ciliary flush and keratic precipitates, which are concerning for uveitis. Together, these findings are consistent with open-angle glaucoma in the setting of uveitis due to deposition of leukocytes within the trabecular meshwork.

Glaucoma is a series of eye diseases resulting in optic nerve damage and subsequent vision loss, often in the setting of increased intraocular pressure. There are two types of glaucoma: open-angle and closed-angle. Open-angle glaucoma is the more common type. The condition can be subdivided into primary disease, which is often idiopathic, and secondary disease, which results from reduced trabecular meshwork outflow due to deposition of leukocytes from uveitis, erythrocytes from vitreous hemorrhage, or scarring.

Closed-angle glaucoma, on the other hand, is caused by narrowing or closure of the iridocorneal angle. In primary disease, for unknown causes, the lens is enlarged and pushes up against the iris, thereby closing the iridocorneal angle. Secondary disease can be due to hypoxia from retinal diseases (e.g., diabetes mellitus, central retinal vein occlusion), which induces neovascularization and causes the iris to be pushed anteriorly. It can also be caused by anticholinergic drugs, which lead to mydriasis and iridocorneal angle narrowing.



Option Analysis

✅ Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Narrowing of the iridocorneal angle:
Incorrect: Closed-angle glaucoma develops when the iridocorneal angle is narrowed or closed and aqueous humor outflow is impaired. The condition is characterized by a painful eye, blurred vision, as well as a non-reactive and dilated pupil. In contrast, this patient has no visual disturbances and a pupil that is reactive to light. As a result, his elevated intraocular pressure is more likely because of open-angle glaucoma secondary to uveitis.
❌ Blockage of the retinal vein:
Incorrect: Retinal vein occlusion is a known cause of secondary closed-angle glaucoma, which can manifest with increased cupping of the optic nerve and elevated intraocular pressure. However, retinal vein occlusion would typically present with retinal hemorrhage, edema, and retinal vessel dilation on fundoscopic examination.
❌ Separation of retina from underlying support tissue:
Incorrect: Retinal detachment can manifest with increased floaters, vision loss, and the sensation that a curtain is coming down into the visual field. On fundoscopic examination, the retina may appear torn or pale. In contrast, these findings are not present in this patient.
❌ Degeneration of the macula:
Incorrect: Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) can result in central vision loss and metamorphopsia, which is a type of visual distortion wherein straight lines appear wavy. However, the condition would not cause elevations in intraocular pressure or cupping of the optic nerve.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent low back pain and stiffness of several weeks duration. The pain is worse in the morning and gradually improves with activity throughout the day. The patient is sexually active and has had four partners in the past year. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates limited spine flexion and tenderness to palpation of the lumbar spine. Laboratory results show a microcytic anemia and an elevated platelet count. An x-ray of the lumbar spine is demonstrated below. Further history is most likely to reveal which of the following clinical features?  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Acute unilateral eye pain and blurring of vision
Erythema in a malar distribution over the cheeks and nose
Chronic dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain
Unilateral or bilateral external ear inflammation

questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy (negative rheumatoid factor) resulting in destruction of articular cartilage and bony ankylosis (fusion of joints)--particularly the sacroiliac joints. The disease commonly presents with low back pain that is worse in the morning and gradually improves throughout the day. In addition, this patient has an radiograph suggestive of AS, given the  “bamboo spine” appearance due to vertebral body fusion. Of the choices listed, only acute unilateral eye pain and blurring of vision, reflective of uveitis, is associated with AS.  

Uveitis is defined by the inflammation of the uvea, which includes the iris, ciliary body, and choroid. Clinically, this condition is characterized by painful red eyes, photophobia, increased tear production, and blurry vision. Uveitis is characterized by the anatomic location of inflammation:  

  •  inflammation of the anterior uveal tract (e.g. iris and ciliary body) is referred to as anterior uveitis and can be seen in systemic inflammatory disorders, such as HLA-B27-associated entities (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis), inflammatory bowel disease, and sarcoidosis. 
  •  inflammation of the posterior uveal tract (e.g. choroid) is referred to as posterior uveitis (synonymous with choroiditis or chorioretinitis) and can be caused by infectious agents (e.g., toxoplasmosis, syphilis) or due to systemic inflammatory conditions (e.g. sarcoidosis).  
Anterior uveitis is characterized by red, painful eye(s), whereas posterior uveitis presents as worsening vision and visual field changes. Eye examination in patients with anterior uveitis reveals a constricted pupil, with leukocytes in the anterior chamber of the eye on slit lamp examination. Ophthalmic examination in posterior uveitis can reveal chorioretinal lesions.   

Option Analysis

✅ Acute unilateral eye pain and blurring of vision:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Genital ulcerations:
Incorrect: Genital ulcerations are common in patients with Behçet syndrome, an autoimmune vasculitis characterized by recurrent aphthae, ocular disease, skin lesions, gastrointestinal symptoms, and arthritis. Instead, the patient in this vignette has ankylosing spondylitis.
❌ Erythema in a malar distribution over the cheeks and nose:
Incorrect: The “butterfly rash” is the most common dermatologic manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus that often appears after sun exposure. 
❌ Chronic dry cough, dyspnea, and chest pain:
Incorrect: A chronic dry cough with dyspnea and chest pain is a common presenting sign in patients with sarcoidosis, not ankylosing spondylitis. 
❌ Unilateral or bilateral external ear inflammation:
Incorrect: Relapsing polychondritis is an immune-mediated condition associated with inflammation in cartilaginous structures. This patient’s symptoms and radiograph suggest ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with visual changes. The patient has been seeing colored halos around lights for the past six months and has also noticed her vision has become progressively blurrier. Since symptom onset, she has not experienced any pain or conjunctival erythema. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and asthma. She is currently retired but formerly worked as a national park ranger. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 151/83 mmHg, and pulse is 76/min. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/70 in the left eye. A slit-lamp examination is shown below. Which of the following is the most common risk factor for the development of this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
