This patient presents with progressively worsening, painless visual disturbances, reduced visual acuity, and lens opacification. She likely has a left-eye cataract. Among the risk factors for cataract formation, increased age is the most common.

Cataracts most frequently develop in adults in the fifth or sixth decades of life. In rarer cases, cataracts can be congenital or arise in pediatric patients. The condition is caused by degenerative processes that denature and coagulate proteins within the ocular lens, resulting in opacification, which impairs transmission of light onto the retina. Etiologies and risk factors are numerous and include both inherited and acquired conditions.

Inherited risk factors include congenital TORCH infections, which includes the organisms toxoplasma, syphilis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus. Additional inherited risk factors include genetic conditions, such as trisomies 13, 18 and 21, Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, Refsum disease, myotonic dystrophy, neurofibromatosis type 2, and inborn errors of metabolism like galactosemia. Acquired risk factors include advanced age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, ultraviolet radiation, prolonged corticosteroid use, smoking, nutritional deficiencies (e.g. vitamin C), and ocular trauma/infections.



Option Analysis

✅ Age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Radiation exposure:
Incorrect: Ultraviolet radiation is a risk factor for the development of cataracts. However, age-related degeneration of the ocular lens is the most common risk factor.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus is a known risk factor for the development of cataracts. This association exists because in patients with hyperglycemia, the excess circulating glucose is converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase. Sorbitol then accumulates in the lens, causing osmotic cellular injury. However, age is a more common risk factor for the development of cataracts.
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Prolonged use of corticosteroid, both local and systemic, is a risk factor for the development of cataracts. While this patient has a history of asthma and has likely experienced exacerbations in the past, there is little evidence of chronic steroid use (e.g., oral thrush, stretch marks, truncal obesity).
❌ In utero rubella infection:
Incorrect: In utero rubella infection is known to cause congenital cataracts. However, this patient is currently in her 70s, and the visual disturbances developed recently, which makes congenital cataracts unlikely the cause of her symptoms.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of  “gritty,” red, itchy eyes for the past three months. The patient has also had intermittent episodes of associated blurry vision. The patient's visual acuity acutely worsens during periods of reading, driving, and watching television. She reports a past medical history of “seasonal allergies” and takes oral antihistamines without relief of symptoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals bilateral conjunctival injection. Visual acuity testing demonstrates 20/80 vision in both eyes bilaterally. Slit-lamp examination using fluorescein stain reveals “spotty” uptake. Oral examination reveals multiple dental caries and halitosis. Laboratory results are demonstrated below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  11.3  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  39 % 
 Leukocyte count  9,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  375,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  5 mm/h 
 Antinuclear antibodies   Negative 
 Rheumatoid factor  Negative 
 Anti-dsDNA  Negative 
 Anti-Ro/La  Negative 
Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Autoimmune destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands

questions.solution:
Keratoconjunctivitis refers to ocular inflammation involving both the cornea and the conjunctiva, and it is divided into infectious and non-infectious etiologies. Infectious keratoconjunctivitis is most commonly caused by viruses--involving adenovirus in greater than 90% of cases.  Among non-infectious causes of keratoconjunctivitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca, also known as dry eye disease, is due to age-related atrophy of the lacrimal glands.   

Keratoconjunctivitis, in addition to typical symptoms of conjunctivitis, also presents with blurry vision due to corneal involvement. A particularly pathognomonic finding is that reading, computer use, television or other electronic use, or driving (when the natural blink reflex is decreased) exacerbates the decreased visual acuity. For keratoconjunctivitis sicca, eye dryness and irritation are common, which are characteristically described as a sensation of sand (“grittiness”) in the eyes. Further diagnostic testing, such as slit lamp examination using fluorescein, may reveal a “spotty” or diffuse uptake stain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Age-related atrophy of glandular tissue  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Allergen-induced ocular inflammation:
Incorrect: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis is a severe allergic conjunctivitis that is likely caused by the immunoglobulin E (IgE) mast cell-mediated pathway. Although this patient has a history of allergies, her current symptoms are not relieved by antihistamines, suggesting another diagnosis. 
❌ Autoimmune destruction of salivary and lacrimal glands:
Incorrect: Although this patient has symptoms suggestive of Sjogren syndrome (e.g., keratoconjunctivitis, dental caries, halitosis), her laboratory results are negative for the autoimmune condition, making this an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Herpes simplex virus reactivation:
Incorrect: HSV reactivation can result in keratoconjunctivitis with similar symptoms; however, diagnosis is confirmed via slit lamp examination, which demonstrates branching dendritic lesions on the cornea--not diffuse uptake. 
❌ Adenovirus-induced ocular inflammation:
Incorrect: Viral keratoconjunctivitis has an associated antecedent upper respiratory illness in up to 50% of cases. Patients initially present with unilateral eye involvement that later spreads to the contralateral eye. Adenovirus-related keratoconjunctivitis typically lasts for a few weeks before self-resolving, making this etiology unlikely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to her opthamologist for vision changes. Over the past year, the patient has been involved in several low-speed motor vehicle accidents after failing to notice incoming traffic. She has not experienced any ocular pain or erythema. Past medical history is notable for Crohn disease, type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. Current medications include infliximab, lisinopril, metformin, metoprolol, and warfarin. Vital signs are within normal limits, and ophthalmologic examination is notable for an intraocular pressure of 25 mmHg in the right eye and 27 mmHg in the left eye. Slit lamp examination reveals thinning of the outer rim of the bilateral optic nerve heads. The patient is also noted to have bilateral peripheral vision loss. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased intraocular pressure, optic nerve thinning, and peripheral vision loss. She likely has glaucoma. In the absence of other associated conditions, her presentation is most consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma, which is an idiopathic etiology.

Open-angle glaucoma refers to glaucoma wherein the angle between the cornea and lens remains open. The condition can be subdivided into primary and secondary disease. The cause of primary disease remains unclear, though research postulates it may be related to a combination of cell loss, circulatory defects, and extracellular matrix factors. Secondary disease results from reduced trabecular meshwork outflow due to deposition of leukocytes from uveitis, erythrocytes from vitreous hemorrhage, or retinal fragments from retinal detachment.

Treatment involves lowering intraocular pressure, which can be accomplished via pharmacological and surgical measures. Medications used to treat glaucoma include those that decrease aqueous humor production, such as beta blockers (e.g. timolol), carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide), and alpha agonists (e.g., apraclonidine, brimonidine). Medications that increase aqueous humor outflow include cholinomimetics (e.g. pilocarpine) and prostaglandins (e.g., bimatoprost, latanoprost). If the patient’s disease is advanced or refractory to medical therapy, then laser iridotomy or trabeculoplasty can be performed.



Option Analysis

✅ Idiopathic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Uveitis:
Incorrect: An acute flare of uveitis can result in deposition of white blood cells in the trabecular meshwork, which can lead to impaired aqueous humor drainage and development of open-angle glaucoma. Although this patient has a history of Crohn disease, there is no information regarding prior uveitis flares or physical examination findings suggestive of a current flare (e.g., red eye, hypopyon).
❌ Vitreous hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Vitreous hemorrhage can result in deposition of red blood cells in the trabecular meshwork, which can lead to impaired aqueous humor drainage and development of open-angle glaucoma. Vitreous hemorrhage can present with blurry vision, floaters, and flashes of light in the visual fields. In contrast, this patient does not have these symptoms.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Observational studies have demonstrated that patients with diabetes are at increased risk for developing glaucoma. However, diabetes mellitus is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of glaucoma.
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Observational studies have demonstrated that patients with hypertension are at increased risk for developing glaucoma. However, hypertension is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of glaucoma.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right eye pain of several hours duration. His mother states, “He’s been fighting something all week. He's been blowing his nose non-stop; I think he had a fever too.” He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 112/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the right orbit with associated right eyelid swelling with erythema. The patient reports significant pain with extraocular eye movement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history suspicious for recent sinusitis is now presenting with eye swelling, pain, and pain with movement of the extraocular eye muscles, consistent with a diagnosis of orbital cellulitis.   

Orbital cellulitis refers to an infection of the connective tissue of the orbit, and it is usually incited by a preceding sinus infection or physical trauma (e.g. bug bite). Symptoms include pain with eye movements, proptosis or bulging of the eyeball, redness and swelling of the eyelid, and in some cases, ophthalmoplegia or impairment of eye movements. This condition is often accompanied by systemic symptoms, such as fever and chills.  

In contrast, preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis, affects only the anterior portion of the eyelid, without actually involving the orbit. This condition does not present with pain with eye movement, though it can progress to orbital cellulitis.  

If orbital cellulitis goes untreated, the infection can extend into deeper intracranial structures, causing meningitis, intracerebral abscess, or sinus venous thrombosis. Treatment involves antibiotics like nafcillin, ceftriaxone, and metronidazole, which cover gram positive organisms.  

Option Analysis

✅ Orbital cellulitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Periorbital cellulitis:
Incorrect: Preseptal cellulitis affects the anterior portion of the eyelid, without actually involving the orbit. Preseptal cellulitis does not present with pain with extraocular eye movements. 
❌ Venous sinus thrombosis:
Incorrect: Venous sinus thrombosis, particularly of the cavernous sinus, is the most devastating complication of orbital cellulitis. This condition presents with a severe headache, photophobia, as well as nausea and vomiting. 
❌ Chalazion:
Incorrect: Chalazions result from the obstruction of sebaceous glands of the eyelids, without an underlying infection. It presents as a slow-growing, painless rubbery nodule, usually in the middle of the upper eyelid. 
❌ Hordeolum:
Incorrect: Hordeolums, also known as styes, are a common bacterial infection of the sebaceous glands of the eyelids that present as painful, red, pus-filled lumps at the lid margin. The most commonly implicated pathogen is Staphylococcus aureus. This patient’s pain with eye movement and fever suggest a more serious infectious process.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a routine check-up. She has been feeling well and has been taking medications as prescribed. The patient lives at a senior apartment complex and is able to complete activities of daily living. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which she takes lisinopril and atorvastatin. The patient does not consume alcohol or tobacco products. Vital signs are within normal limits. On ophthalmologic evaluation, intraocular pressures are measured to be 25 mmHg in the right eye and 27 mmHg in the left eye. Fundoscopic examination reveals the following:


Image reproduced from Flickr

 If untreated, this patient will most likely develop which of the following findings?

choices.text: Small shadows in the visual field

questions.solution:
This patient has a painless elevation of intraocular pressure (>20 mmHg) and enlarged cup-to-disc ratio. These findings are concerning for open-angle glaucoma, which, if untreated, can cause peripheral vision loss.

Glaucoma is an eye disease that results in damage to the optic nerve and subsequent vision loss, often in the setting of increased intraocular pressure. The pathophysiology of glaucoma can be understood by tracing the normal flow of aqueous humor through the eye. Aqueous humor is produced by the ciliary body and exits the posterior chamber via the pupil into the anterior chamber. Next, aqueous humor exits the eye either via the trabecular network and canals of Schlemm to aqueous veins, or via the uveo-scleral pathway.

Open-angle glaucoma can be idiopathic or due to reduced aqueous humor flow through the trabecular meshwork. Closed-angle glaucoma occurs when the iridocorneal angle is narrowed, thus impeding aqueous humor outflow.

In both conditions, impaired aqueous humor outflow can result in increased intraocular pressure, optic disc atrophy, and progressive peripheral vision loss. Open-angle glaucoma is usually discovered incidentally, since the majority of patients are asymptomatic in the early stages of disease. In contrast, closed-angle glaucoma results in acute attacks characterized by a unilateral, painful eye with a non-reactive and dilated pupil.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Peripheral vision loss:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of central vision:
Incorrect: This patient presents with elevated intraocular pressures and an enlarged cup-to-disc ratio, which are concerning for glaucoma. Although glaucoma can ultimately result in central vision loss, peripheral vision loss tends to occur first and is a more common clinical finding.
❌ Amaurosis fugax:
Incorrect: Amaurosis fugax describes a painless temporary loss of vision in one or both eyes. The condition is usually caused by imapired blood flow to the eye, such as in the case of retinal artery occlusion. In contrast, this patient more likely has glaucoma, which is initially asymptomatic but overtime can lead to peripheral vision loss.
❌ Difficulty seeing in dim light:
Incorrect: Retinitis pigmentosa is a form of inherited retinal degeneration that leads to progressive vision loss. The first symptoms are often night blindness due to degeneration of the rods in the retina.
❌ Small shadows in the visual field:
Incorrect: Floaters, which are little “cobwebs” or “specks” that float in the visual field, arise due to the presence of objects (e.g. leukocytes, erythrocytes) within the vitreous fluid. Floaters can develop in the setting of vitreous detachment, intraocular bleeding, and uveitis, but not typically glaucoma.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with acute-onset, right-sided eye pain. She was in a movie theater when she suddenly experienced severe pain in the right eye and associated blurry vision. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. She smokes 1-2 cigarettes per day and does not consume alcohol or illicit substances. Review of the medical record shows the patient’s most recent hemoglobin A1C was 5.7%. Ophthalmologic examination is notable for the following finding:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The right pupil is unresponsive to light. Bilateral retina are successfully visualized, and increased optic nerve cupping is observed in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Anatomically shallow anterior chamber with lens enlargement

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute-onset eye pain. Physical examination reveals a dilated right pupil non-reactive to light, with surrounding injection and increased optic nerve cupping. Together, these findings are consistent with acute closed-angle glaucoma, which in the absence of other precipitating factors, is most commonly due to an enlarged lens that gets pushed up against the iris in individuals with an anatomically shallow anterior chamber.

Closed-angle glaucoma is caused by narrowing or closure of the iridocorneal angle. This abnormality leads to impaired aqueous humor outflow, increased intraocular pressure, and ischemia of intraocular structures. Closed-angle glaucoma can be divided into primary and secondary disease.

Primary disease is due to an enlarged lens that gets pushed up against the iris in individuals with an anatomically shallow anterior chamber. The condition often develops when the patient is in a low-light environment, since it triggers pupillary dilation and iris contraction, which crowds the iridocorneal angle. Secondary disease can be due to hypoxia from retinal diseases (e.g., diabetes mellitus, central retinal vein occlusion), which induces neovascularization and causes the iris to be pushed anteriorly. It can also be caused by anticholinergic drugs, which lead to mydriasis and reduced aqueous humor outflow.

Acute closed-angle glaucoma often manifests with increased intraocular pressure on tonometry, a dilated pupil unresponsive to light with surrounding injection, severe pain, blurred vision, as well as nausea and vomiting. Chronic closed-angle glaucoma occurs when the increase in intraocular pressure happens gradually, and it will often present with progressive vision loss due to optic nerve damage.



Option Analysis

✅ Anatomically shallow anterior chamber with lens enlargement:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retinal vein occlusion:
Incorrect: Retinal vein occlusion is a known cause of secondary acute closed-angle glaucoma. The condition can present with retinal hemorrhage, edema, and retinal vessel dilation on fundoscopic examination. In contrast, this patient’s retinal examination demonstrates only optic nerve cupping.
❌ Medication side effect:
Incorrect: Medications with antimuscarinic properties like atropine can precipitate episodes of secondary closed-angle glaucoma. In contrast, amlodipine does not predispose patients to closed-angle glaucoma.
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetes mellitus can result in neovascularization and precipitate secondary closed-angle glaucoma. However, this patient’s hemoglobin A1C is within normal limits, hence making underlying diabetes unlikely.
❌ Opacification of the lens:
Incorrect: Cataracts are characterized by opacification of the ocular lens. However, cataracts are not known to cause closed-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with painless worsening of vision. Over the past five months, his vision has become more blurry. He has also experienced difficulty driving at night, since light from incoming cars causes an unbearable glare. Medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient does not use glasses or contact lenses. Visual acuity is 20/30 in the right eye and 20/100 in the left eye. A fundoscopic examination reveals a reduced red reflex in the left eye. No conjunctival erythema is present, and pupillary response is intact bilaterally. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with blurry vision and increased sensitivity to glare, and ocular examination demonstrates a reduced red reflex. He likely has a cataract, which is due to lens opacification.

Cataracts most commonly develop in adults in the fifth or sixth decades of life. In rare cases, cataracts can be congenital or arise in pediatric patients. The condition is caused by degenerative processes that denature and coagulate proteins within the ocular lens, resulting in opacification, which imapirs transmission of light onto the retina.

Clinically, cataracts present with gradual, unilateral or bilateral, painless visual changes. Visual changes often include blurred vision, colored halos around lights, sensitivity to light/glare, as well as fading or yellowing of objects. On physical examination, patients will demonstrate decreased visual acuity, opacification of all or part of the lens, as well as reduced red reflex. In both children and adults, cataracts may also present with leukoria, which is an abnormal white reflection from the retina of the eye.



Option Analysis

✅ Opacification of the lens:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inflammation of the uvea:
Incorrect: Uveitis refers to inflammation of the uvea and can manifest with ocular pain, conjunctival injection, and imapired vision. In contrast, this patient presents with painless reduction of visual acuity, increased glare, and a reduced red reflex, which are more concerning for a cataract.
❌ Abnormal curvature of the cornea:
Incorrect: Astigmatism refers to an abnormal curvature of the cornea that results in difficulty seeing both near and far objects. However, astigmatism would not account for the reduced red reflex or increased sensitivity to glare.
❌ Optic disc atrophy:
Incorrect: Glaucoma manifests as optic disc atrophy in the setting of elevated intraocular pressures. The condition typically causes progressive peripheral vision loss. Glaucoma would not, however, lead to a reduced red reflex.
❌ Malignant proliferation of retinal cells:
Incorrect: Retinoblastoma is primarily diagnosed in children, and over 95% of cases are diagnosed before the age of 5. It commonly manifests with leukoria, which is an abnormal white reflection from the retina of the eye. Given this patient’s age, his symptoms are more likely due to cataract formation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to this primary care physician for a routine evaluation. The patient has a long history of uncontrolled hypertension and has been on several medications with minimal efficacy. He has a 25-pack-year smoking history and drinks 4-5 beers on the weekends. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 188/98 mmHg. He appears comfortable and in no acute distress. Which of the following is likely to be observed on fundoscopic examination in this patient?

choices.text: Enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio
Formation of new retinal blood vessels
Pale, opaque, and wrinkled retinal tissue

questions.solution:
The retinal blood supply sustains a series of pathophysiological changes in response to chronic hypertension. Blood vessel vasoconstriction is due to autoregulatory mechanisms and generalized narrowing of the retinal arterioles. Over time, persistently elevated blood pressure leads to intimal thickening and hyperplasia of the media with focal areas of arteriolar narrowing and changes in the arteriolar and venular junctions (i.e., arteriovenous nicking). This phenomenon occurs when an arteriole with a thick arteriosclerotic wall compresses the overlying vein.  

Over time, arteriosclerotic blood vessels burst, compromising the blood-retinal barrier--ensuing retinal ischemia, necrosis of smooth muscle cells, endothelial cells, and exudation of both blood and lipids. These changes appear as microaneurysms, hemorrhages, hard exudates, and cotton-wool spots on fundoscopy. In severe cases, papilledema or swelling of the optic disk may be seen. Treatment of hypertensive retinopathy requires both immediate and long-term control of blood pressure.

Option Analysis

✅ Arteriovenous nicking   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio:
Incorrect: This finding suggests open-angle glaucoma, which typically presents as progressive peripheral vision loss associated with an enlarged optic cup and increased cup/disc ratio (“cupping” of the optic disc).   
❌ Formation of new retinal blood vessels   :
Incorrect: Formation of new blood vessels (neovascularization) can be seen in advanced stages of diabetic retinopathy. Capillary malperfusion leads to retinal ischemia, upregulation of pro-angiogenic cytokines (vascular endothelial growth factor), and pathological intra-retinal neovascularization. These vessels are typically fenestrated, fragile, and leaky.   
❌ Pale, opaque, and wrinkled retinal tissue   :
Incorrect: Retinal detachment initially presents as light flashes or floaters followed by sudden visual field loss in the affected eye. This condition typically begins with peripheral visual field loss, progressing towards a loss of central vision. Diagnosis is based on a fundoscopic examination, which may demonstrate wrinkling of retinal tissue or changes in blood vessel direction.   
❌ Presence of drusen   :
Incorrect: Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is characterized by yellowish extracellular deposits accumulating between the Bruch membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium. AMD typically presents with impaired central vision and decreased visual acuity (e.g., difficulty reading or driving).

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a sudden painless vision loss in her right eye. The patient experienced scintillations and blurry vision in her right eye earlier in the day before complete vision loss. She has a history of deep vein thrombosis. Vitals are within normal limits. Pupils are equal and reactive to light, and extraocular muscle movements are intact. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye reveals dilated tortuous veins and intraretinal hemorrhages. The optic disc margins are obscured by edema and hemorrhage. Fundoscopy of the left eye is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Thrombus in the central retinal vein
Embolus in the central retinal artery
Atherosclerotic disease of the ipsilateral carotid artery
Separation of retinal tissue from underlying retinal pigment epithelium
Extensive intraocular deposition of extracellular drusen

questions.solution:
Retinal vein occlusion occurs secondary to thrombus formation of the central retinal vein (CRVO) or one of its branches (BRVO). Patients often have a history of cardiovascular disease or thrombophilia (e.g., polycythemia vera, factor V Leiden).  

CRVO manifests as an acute, painless monocular vision loss. Diagnosis relies on fundoscopic examination, which typically reveals optic disc swelling, retinal hemorrhages, and dilated veins that provide a characteristic “blood and thunder appearance.” Treatment includes laser photocoagulation and steroid or anti-VEGF injections.  


Reproduced from: Flickr

Option Analysis

✅ Thrombus in the central retinal vein   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Embolus in the central retinal artery   :
Incorrect: Cardiogenic emboli is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) in younger individuals (whereas atherosclerotic disease of the ipsilateral carotid artery is the most common cause of CRAO in elderly individuals). For this condition, fundoscopic examination demonstrates a pale retina, narrowing of blood vessels, and a “cherry-red spot”.   
❌ Atherosclerotic disease of the ipsilateral carotid artery   :
Incorrect: Atherosclerotic disease of the ipsilateral carotid artery is the most common overall cause of central retinal artery occlusion in elderly individuals. Fundoscopic examination demonstrates a pale retina, narrowing of blood vessels, and a “cherry-red spot”.   
❌ Separation of retinal tissue from underlying retinal pigment epithelium   :
Incorrect: Retinal detachment presents with light flashes or floaters described followed by sudden visual field loss in the affected eye. Vision loss typically begins in the periphery and progresses toward loss of the central visual axis over hours to weeks. A fundoscopic examination may demonstrate wrinkling/crinkling of retinal tissue or changes in blood vessel direction.   
❌ Extensive intraocular deposition of extracellular drusen   :
Incorrect: Dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is characterized by yellowish extracellular deposits accumulating between the Bruch membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium. AMD typically presents with impaired central vision and decreased visual acuity (e.g., difficulty reading or driving).

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following sudden-onset, painless monocular vision loss of his left eye. His past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Auscultation over the left neck reveals a bruit. An erythrocyte sedimentation rate is sent and is within normal limits. Fundoscopic examination of the left eye reveals the findings demonstrated below. The patient is initiated on hyperbaric oxygen therapy and begins ocular massage of the left eye. This patient is at risk for which of the following complications?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with multiple atherosclerotic risk factors presents with sudden-onset, painless monocular vision loss, a carotid bruit, and fundoscopic findings consistent with central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). An occluding embolism may originate from the ipsilateral carotid artery or the heart. In older patients, carotid atherosclerosis is the most common etiology for retinal artery occlusion but is unusual in patients under 40. A cardiogenic embolism should be suspected in younger patients presenting with this condition.

CRAO fundoscopic findings include a pale, cloudy retina with narrow blood vessels and a characteristic "cherry-red spot" overlying the fovea. This later finding occurs due to the presence of a pale ischemic retina, while the well-vascularized macula remains intact (the macula receives its blood supply from the choroid plexus, not the central retinal artery), at the same time,  the surrounding retina is pale and ischemic due to retinal artery occlusion. Treatment includes hyperbaric oxygen therapy to enhance oxygen delivery to ischemic retinal tissue. In addition, ocular massage is thought to enhance the breakdown of the thrombus.  

Diagnosis of CRAO in elderly patients suggests a high burden of carotid atherosclerosis, which carries a high risk developing an ischemic stroke. The stroke rate following a CRAO is as high as 13% in the first year and ten times higher than in the general population. Cardiovascular mortality (myocardial infarction) is also high following a CRAO.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ischemic stroke   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage   :
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage typically occurs secondary to rupturing a saccular (berry) aneurysm. This patient’s presentation consistent with central retinal artery occlusion puts him at increased risk for ischemic stroke.   
❌ Deep venous thrombosis   :
Incorrect: The risk of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) is increased in patients with an underlying hypercoagulable state. This patient’s presentation is consistent with central retinal artery occlusion, which puts him at increased risk for ischemic stroke.   
❌ Pulmonary embolism   :
Incorrect: The risk of developing a pulmonary embolism (PE) is increased in patients with an underlying hypercoagulable state. This patient’s presentation consistent with central retinal artery occlusion puts him at increased risk for ischemic stroke.   
❌ Polymyalgia rheumatica   :
Incorrect: Giant cell (temporal) arteritis is a rare cause of central retinal artery occlusion secondary to vasculitis inflammation of the central retinal artery. This patient’s erythrocyte sedimentation rate is within normal limits, mainly negating this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the ophthalmology clinic due to progressively worsening vision over the past several months. The patient states that she has difficulty driving--particularly at dusk and at night. Her mother states the patient has seemed “clumsier”, often running into tables and cabinets. The patient is otherwise healthy.  Vitals are within normal limits. Bilateral corneas appear unremarkable. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. The red reflex is present bilaterally. Visual field testing demonstrates mild loss of peripheral visual fields. Which of the following ophthalmologic structures reflects the primary site of pathology for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents with visual disturbance (particularly in dark light) and visual loss in the mid-peripheral visual fields. These findings are highly suggestive of retinitis pigmentosa (RP), which comprises a group of inherited conditions that result in progressive retinal degeneration of photoreceptors and retinal pigment epithelium. Family history is identified in approximately 70 percent of patients.  

RP presents with painless, progressive vision loss and characteristically begins with night blindness (nyctalopia) and peripheral vision disturbance. In later stages, RP affects central vision. Retinitis pigmentosa received its name from the characteristic fundoscopic findings of spicule-shaped dark blotches surrounding the macula. Additional fundoscopic findings of RP include bone spicule pigmentation, attenuation of retinal vessels, and waxy pallor of the optic nerve.

 

Option Analysis

❌ A :
Incorrect: This area refers to the cornea, which can be affected in conditions such as keratitis, corneal abrasions, or ulcers. Pathology in this anatomic location often results in pain, increased tearing, or  foreign body sensation.   
❌ B   :
Incorrect: This structure is the lens and cataract formation site. Cataracts can present with diminished nighttime vision; however, patients also present with decreased visual acuity, lens reflex loss, and opacification.   
❌ C   :
Incorrect: The vitreous body is the clear gel filling the lens and the retina space. If the vitreous pulls away from the retina, vitreous detachment ensues. This condition is characterized by photopsia (flashes of lights) and floaters.   
✅ D  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ E:
Incorrect: The optic nerve (CN II) transmits visual information from the retina to the brain. Optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve and is associated with several diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Patients typically experience episodic vision loss and eye pain.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician to evaluate the progressive bilateral vision loss. The patient states that she has had difficulty reading and driving, which has gotten worse over the past six weeks. She states that door frames and window blinds appear “curved”. She has a past medical history of hypertension and a 40 pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. A dilated eye examination reveals subretinal fluid with a gray-green discoloration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s ocular condition?

choices.text: Separation of the retinal tissue from the retinal pigment epithelium

questions.solution:
Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a progressive, chronic disease of the central retina and a leading cause of vision loss worldwide. Degeneration of the central retina (the macula), results in loss of central vision. AMD typically starts after age 50, with more pronounced symptoms ensuing over age 65. AMD can be divided into dry (non-exudative) AMD, which accounts for more than 80% of all cases, and wet (exudative) AMD accounts for the remaining 10-15%.  

  • Dry AMD is characterized by drusen (yellow extracellular deposits identified by the blue circle in the image below) that accumulate between the Bruch membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium. Dry AMD is thought to occur secondary to excessive oxidative damage, and current therapies include supplements to combat free radicals (e.g., vitamin C, vitamin E, copper supplements).  
 
  •  In contrast, wet ARMD occurs secondary to neovascularization, where blood vessels grow from the choroid obscuring the macula (as identified by the green circle in the image below). Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) is a crucial regulator of angiogenesis and is a major therapeutic target. Anti-VEGF Medications such as bevacizumab and ranibizumab are often used to treat this condition. 
Patients with dry ARMD typically present with gradual vision problems, whereas patients with wet AMD present with rapid central vision loss over weeks to months. In both conditions, a common clinical finding is metamorphopsia--a type of visual distortion where linear objects (e.g., door frames, window blinds) appear curved or discontinuous. Additionally, scotomas, or areas of patchy vision loss, may also be present.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Option Analysis

✅ Choroidal neovascularization:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Retinal vein compression   :
Incorrect: Compression of the retinal vein occurs in patients with acute central retinal vein occlusion, which typically presents with acute monocular vision loss. Fundoscopy may reveal optic disc swelling, retinal hemorrhages, and dilated veins, giving a characteristic “blood and thunder appearance”. This patient’s vision loss is progressive and bilateral.   
❌ Elevated intraocular pressure:
Incorrect: Elevated intraocular pressure can be seen in patients with glaucoma. Open-angle glaucoma is characterized by marked changes arising in the peripheral field of vision before any changes are noted in central visual acuity. Additionally, this patient’s fundoscopic examination is suggestive of a different condition.   
❌ Embolic occlusion of retinal artery   :
Incorrect: Occlusion of the retinal artery can be seen in patients with central retinal artery occlusion, which typically presents with acute monocular vision loss. Fundoscopic examination typically shows a retina with a cloudy appearance with attenuated vessels and the characteristic "cherry-red" spot in the fovea or center of the macula.   
❌ Separation of the retinal tissue from the retinal pigment epithelium   :
Incorrect: Retinal detachment typically presents as light flashes or floaters described as fine dots, veils, cobwebs, clouds, or strings, followed by sudden visual field loss in the affected eye. This typically begins in the periphery and progresses toward the central visual axis over hours to weeks like a “curtain drawn down.” Diagnosis is based on a fundoscopic examination, which may demonstrate “crinkling” of retinal tissue or abrupt changes in angiogenesis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her ophthalmologist for evaluation of decreased visual acuity. She states her vision in both eyes has been worsening over the past six months. The patient has a history of poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Vitals are within normal limits. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral retinal hemorrhages, hard exudates, and angiogenesis circumferential to the retina in both eyes. Which of the following growth factors is responsible for these fundoscopic features?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of diabetic retinopathy, which refers to retinal damage secondary to long-standing, poorly controlled diabetes. This ophthalmologic disease gets classified into two subtypes:  

  • Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy--where damaged capillaries from long-standing hyperglycemia leak blood into the retina 
  • Proliferative chronic hypoxia results in neovascularization, or the formation of fragile new blood vessels that break and bleed into the retina.  
Diagnosis of either form of diabetic retinopathy relies on fundoscopic examination. Early signs of diabetic retinopathy (non-proliferative and proliferative) include microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots. Both microaneurysms and dot hemorrhages appear as small, red lesions overlying the fundus.

Microhemorrhage and fluid leakage from microaneurysms result in localized edema that leaves behind lipoprotein deposits (“exudates”). Cotton wool spots appear as fluffy white patches on the retina and are secondary to damage to retinal nerve fibers.  

As diabetic retinopathy progresses, retinal ischemia causes upregulation of pro-angiogenic cytokines, namely, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) that drives pathological intra-retinal neovascularization. These vessels are typically fenestrated, fragile, and leaky, resulting in vitreous hemorrhage. Repeated vitreous hemorrhage is associated with fibrovascular scar formation and decreased visual acuity.

Option Analysis

❌ Epidermal growth factor   :
Incorrect: Epidermal growth factor (EGF) belongs to the EGF family, which also includes TGF-α. EGF is a mitogenic factor produced by macrophages and epithelial cells that form granulation tissue.   
❌ Keratinocyte growth factor   :
Incorrect: Keratinocyte growth factor (KGF) stimulates keratinocyte migration, proliferation, and differentiation. This growth factor is involved in areas of wound healing.   
❌ Transforming growth factor-α   :
Incorrect: TGF-α belongs to the epidermal growth factor (EGF) family. Like epidermal growth factor, TGF-α is a mitogenic factor produced by macrophages and epithelial cells that results in the formation of granulation tissue.   
❌ Transforming growth factor-β   :
Incorrect: TGF-β drives scar formation by stimulating the synthesis of the extracellular matrix via decreased matrix metalloproteinase activity and increased activity of tissue inhibitors of proteinases.   
✅ Vascular endothelial growth factor   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department to evaluate sudden-onset painless visual disturbance of her right eye. The patient initially saw floaters and flashes of light in her right eye. Since then, she reports progressive worsening of vision, endorsing a “curtain veil” coming over her right visual field. Her past medical history includes diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Vitals are within normal limits. Fundoscopy demonstrates crinkling of retinal tissue and changes in blood vessel direction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the neurosensory layer of the retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium--resulting in degeneration of photoreceptors and, without treatment, complete vision loss. The most common etiology of this condition is retinal breaks, which often occur secondary to head trauma or vitreous degeneration.  Significant vitreous degeneration increases traction on the retina and potentially a retinal tear. Liquefied vitreous seeps through the tear and under the retina, promoting detachment.  

Patients (especially on examination questions) typically present with the sensation of light flashes or floaters described as fine dots, veils, cobwebs, clouds, or strings, followed by sudden visual field loss in the affected eye. As the retina detaches, it may create a mechanical depolarization of the axons running through the nerve fiber layer of the retina, resulting in the sensation of flashing bright lights. Vision loss typically begins in the periphery and progresses toward the central visual axis over hours to weeks like a “curtain drawn down.” Diagnosis is based on a fundoscopic examination, which may visualize crinkling of retinal tissue or changes in blood vessel direction. Retinal detachment is an emergency and requires urgent surgery to restore sensory function.  

Option Analysis

✅ Retinal detachment   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Choroidal rupture   :
Incorrect: Choroidal rupture occurs in the setting of blunt trauma to the eye. Ophthalmoscopic examination reveals white or yellow streaks concentric to the optic disc.   
❌ Central retinal vein occlusion   :
Incorrect: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) can also present with sudden-onset, painless, monocular vision loss. Fundoscopic findings demonstrate engorged retinal veins and a “blood and thunder” appearance.   
❌ Proliferative diabetic retinopathy   :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of diabetes, her clinical and fundoscopic presentation is not consistent with this diagnosis. Fundoscopic findings of proliferative diabetic retinopathy include a net of neovascularization over the surface of the optic disc.   
❌ Central retinal artery occlusion   :
Incorrect: Central retinal artery occlusion results in sudden, painless monocular vision loss as well--often secondary to the carotid or cardiogenic embolism. Fundoscopy typically reveals a “cherry-red” spot overlying the fovea and a pale ischemic retina.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife to evaluate his altered mental status. The wife states her husband complained of headache and blurry vision earlier that morning with associated nausea and vomiting. He tried taking acetaminophen with minimal relief. His past medical history includes hypertension and a 35 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 158/98 mmHg. There is spontaneous flexion of the hips with passive flexion of the neck. Which of the following findings on fundoscopy contraindicates the performance of a diagnostic lumbar puncture?

choices.text: Edematous optic disc with blurred margins
Enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio
Extensive retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, altered mental status, and a positive Brudzinski sign--concerning meningitis. Unless contraindicated, every patient with suspected meningitis should undergo lumbar puncture (LP). Suppose a lumbar puncture is performed in the setting of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In that case,  a cerebral herniation may ensue due to the rapid change in intracavitary pressure as cerebrospinal fluid is removed for analysis. Any diagnostic physical exam findings that suggest elevated ICP (e.g., papilledema) prohibit the performance of this procedure.  

Papilledema refers to swelling of the optic disc and has multiple etiologies. Meningitis may cause elevated ICP via obstructive hydrocephalus or impaired cerebrospinal fluid absorption due to  inflammation at the level of arachnoid granulations. Fundoscopic findings of papilledema demonstrate an enlarged blind spot and an elevated, edematous disc, with blurred disc margins and engorged blood vessels.  



Option Analysis

✅ Edematous optic disc with blurred margins   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio   :
Incorrect: This finding suggests open-angle glaucoma, which typically presents as progressive peripheral vision loss with findings of an enlarged optic cup with an increased cup/disc ratio (“cupping” of the optic disc) on fundoscopy.   
❌ Extensive retinal hemorrhage and venous engorgement   :
Incorrect: This fundoscopic finding is often observed in patients with retinal vein occlusion. Patients typically present with sudden onset, painless, monocular vision loss.   
❌ Retinal neovascularization   :
Incorrect: Formation of new blood vessels (neovascularization) is often seen in the advanced stages of diabetic retinopathy. This finding occurs secondary to retinal ischemia and subsequent upregulation of pro-angiogenic cytokines, namely, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). Neovascularization is not a contraindication to the performance of a lumbar puncture.   
❌ Crinkling of retinal tissue   :
Incorrect: Retinal detachment typically presents as flashes or floaters followed by sudden, painless visual field loss in the affected eye. Vision loss typically begins in the periphery and progresses toward loss of the central visual axis over hours to weeks. A fundoscopic examination may demonstrate wrinkling/crinkling of retinal tissue or changes in blood vessel direction. These fundoscopic findings do not suggest papilledema and hence do not contraindicate the performance of a lumbar puncture.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the ophthalmologist after his primary care doctor noted ocular malalignment. He was born at full term without complications. The patient has been growing well along with the 50th percentile for height and weight. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals malalignment of the right eye. Examination with an ophthalmoscope reveals a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. Dilated fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown below. Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor
Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions

questions.solution:
This young child presents with strabismus, leukocoria, and fundoscopy findings consistent with retinoblastoma. This retinal tumor of childhood is caused by a mutation in both alleles of the retinoblastoma or RB1 gene on chromosome 13. Retinoblastomas can be hereditary, in which case the individual inherits a mutation in one of the alleles of the RB1 gene; however, random mutations in this gene may also lead to the development of retinoblastoma. Hereditary retinoblastomas are typically bilateral and are associated with an increased risk of developing additional malignancies, including osteosarcoma, sarcomas, and melanoma. Sporadic retinoblastomas tend to be unilateral.  

Clinical features of retinoblastoma include leukocoria or “white pupil” with red reflex testing. Typically, reflected light from the fundus appears red; however, a tumor that grows over the fundus blocks reflected light such that the pupil appears white. Other common symptoms include strabismus (misalignment of the eyes), nystagmus, or ocular inflammation. Metastases to the brain are common, presenting with findings of vomiting, headaches, or neurologic deficits. Diagnosis of retinoblastoma begins with a red reflex testing, followed by a fundoscopic examination. Characteristic findings on fundoscopy include the presence of a chalky, off-white retinal mass with a soft, friable consistency. A biopsy is not necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Definitive treatment depends on the extent of disease progression, but in early stages typically consists of enucleation or complete removal of the eye.  

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired inhibition of E2F transcription factor   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Hypermethylation of DNA repair gene promoter regions   :
Incorrect: Patients with hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)  inherited germline mutations in DNA-repair genes, resulting in hypermethylation of these crucial repair proteins.   
❌ Increased B-catenin synthesis   :
Incorrect: The APC gene encodes a cytoplasmic protein that promotes the degradation of B-catenin. Mutation in the APC gene develops colonic polyps, not retinoblastoma.   
❌ Loss of serine-threonine kinase activity   :
Incorrect: Mutations in the LKB1 or STK11 gene are present in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. These genes encode a tumor suppressor protein involved in cell signaling and apoptosis. Loss of kinase activity of STK11 is associated with deranged growth suppression function. Patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome characteristically have a hyperpigmented perioral area, along with an increased risk for gastrointestinal cancers.   
❌ Impaired production of p53 protein   :
Incorrect: A mutation in the TP53 gene reduces the production of the tumor suppressor protein p53. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a rare cancer-predisposition syndrome caused by autosomal dominant mutations in the TP53 gene. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is also known as sarcoma, breast, leukemia, and adrenal gland (SBLA) cancer syndrome.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female preschool teacher presents to an urgent care for evaluation of right eye discharge and foreign body sensation for the past 2 days. One week ago, the patient had a sore throat and low-grade fever that self-resolved after several days. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 11/min, blood pressure is 102/84 mm Hg. Right eye examination demonstrates a follicular appearance of the tarsal conjunctiva and profuse watery discharge. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also present. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young teacher, who presents with a history of a viral syndrome and subsequent symptoms of unilateral conjunctival injection and associated watery discharge, likely has viral conjunctivitis. The most common viral etiology of conjunctivitis is adenovirus.   

Distinguishing between bacterial, viral and allergic conjunctivitis is primarily achieved on the basis of history and physical examination. Viral conjunctivitis should be suspected in patients with a viral prodrome (e.g., pharyngitis, low-grade fever, upper respiratory infection), whereas allergic conjunctivitis should be suspected in patients with a history of seasonal allergies or atopy. The character of ocular discharge is also helpful in determining the etiology of the conjunctivitis. Viral and allergic conjunctivitis typically have a watery consistency with strands of mucus, whereas bacterial conjunctivitis results in thick purulent discharge. Allergic conjunctivitis is nearly always bilateral, whereas viral and bacterial conjunctivitis tend to be unilateral (although the presence of bilateral conjunctivitis should not immediately rule out these etiologies).

 

Option Analysis

✅ Adenovirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Allergens:
Incorrect: Allergic conjunctivitis is caused by airborne allergens that trigger a type I immunoglobulin E (IgE)-mediated hypersensitivity response. In the eye, this condition typically manifests with bilateral conjunctival injection, watery discharge, and itching (the cardinal symptom of an ocular allergic response).
❌ Chlamydia trachomatis:
Incorrect: Although bacterial conjunctivitis can result in unilateral ocular discharge, it is more often purulent. This patient’s history of a viral syndrome (e.g. low-grade fever, pharyngitis) are suggestive of a different etiology. 
❌ Neisseria gonorrhoeae :
Incorrect: Although bacterial conjunctivitis can result in unilateral ocular discharge, it is more often purulent. This patient’s history of a viral syndrome (e.g. low-grade fever, pharyngitis) are suggestive of a different etiology. 
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: S. aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults, which more commonly presents with purulent discharge. Additionally, this patient’s prodromal viral symptoms (e.g., low-grade fever, pharyngitis) are suggestive of a different etiology.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician’s office for evaluation of right eye pain for three days. She had a similar episode several years ago that self-resolved without medical treatment. She has no history of ocular trauma. The patient’s past medical history includes rosacea. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a tender, erythematous papule at the inferior margin of the right eyelid as shown in the image below.  

 

 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following pathogens is most likely implicated in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a tender, erythematous papule at the inferior margin of the right eyelid, consistent with a hordeolum (stye). A stye, also known as a hordeolum, refers to a bacterial infection of the sebaceous glands of the eyelids. The most commonly implicated pathogen is Staphylococcus aureus.   

It is important to differentiate hordeolums from chalazions, which have similar clinical presentations. Chalazions result from the obstruction of sebaceous glands of the eyelids, without an associated underlying infection. In contrast to styes, which present acutely as a painful, red, pus-filled nodule located at the inferior lid margin, chalazions occur subacutely and often under the conjunctival side of the upper eyelid. In addition, these lesions present as a slow-growing, painless (as opposed to painful nodules caused by hordeolums), rubbery nodule.  

Hordeolums tend to be more common in individuals with a history of acne vulgaris, rosacea, seborrheic dermatitis, and diabetes mellitus. Additionally, patients who wear extensive, or heavy eye makeup can induce the formation of hordeola by directly blocking proper drainage of gland pores. Diagnosis is clinical, and treatment involves warm compresses and orbital massage in order to facilitate drainage. Rarely, patients who do not respond to first-line therapy may benefit from topical antibiotics specifically targeting S. aureus.   

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcus aureus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Staphylococcus epidermidis:
Incorrect:S. epidermidis is not commonly implicated in the development of hordeolums (styes). 
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are more commonly implicated in orbital cellulitis, which refers to an infection of the connective tissue surrounding the orbit. It often occurs secondary to sinusitis, particularly ethmoiditis in young children. Symptoms include pain with eye movements, proptosis or bulging of the eyeball, redness and swelling of the eyelid, and in some cases, ophthalmoplegia or impairment of eye movement.
❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect:  Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are more commonly implicated in orbital cellulitis, which refers to an infection of the connective tissue surrounding the orbit. It often occurs secondary to sinusitis, particularly ethmoiditis in young children. Symptoms include pain with eye movements, proptosis or bulging of the eyeball, redness and swelling of the eyelid, and in some cases, ophthalmoplegia or impairment of eye movement.
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: P. aeruginosa is not commonly implicated in the development of hordeolums (styes).

questions.text:
A 1-day-old girl is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for evaluation of jaundice and microcephaly. The infant was delivered by cesarean section at 36 weeks due to fetal growth restriction. Hepatosplenomegaly, intracranial calcifications and microcephaly were detected by ultrasonography during the patients gestation. The mother remained in the northeast United States for the duration of her pregnancy and did not travel. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates jaundice and widespread petechiae. The liver is palpable 5 cm below the costal margin. MRI brain reveals hydrocephalus and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Fundoscopy is notable for the finding as demonstrated below. Which of the following maternal exposures is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This premature neonate presents with jaundice, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, extramedullary hematopoiesis, petechiae (also commonly referred to as a “blueberry muffin” rash), hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications -- a presentation consistent with congenital toxoplasmosis. Infection with toxoplasmosis occurs by either consumption of tissue cysts present in raw or undercooked meat or by ingesting oocysts in the feces of cats, which can cross the maternal-placental barrier. One of the common features of this infection is chorioretinitis, a type of uveitis.  

Many of the TORCH infections can cause chorioretinitis as a complication. Chorioretinitis refers to a subtype of uveitis involving the posterior segment of the eye, inflaming the choroid and the retina of the eye. Toxoplasma gondii is the most common cause of infectious posterior uveitis worldwide. Ophthalmic examination of a patient with chorioretinitis will reveal inflammation of both retina and choroid, which appear as yellow-white lesions as above. Inflammation of these layers can lead to blindness if left untreated.    

Option Analysis

✅ Consumption of undercooked pork:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Consumption of raw fish:
Incorrect: Consumption of raw fish during pregnancy can expose the fetus to environmental pollutants, such as methylmercury. Mercury exposure can damage the developing fetal central nervous system. 
❌ Consumption of unpasteurized cheeses:
Incorrect: Listeria is a common contaminant found in processed/delicatessen meats and soft cheeses. Listeriosis in pregnancy most often occurs in the third trimester, resulting in fetal death, premature birth, or sepsis in the newborn. 
❌ Infected mosquitos :
Incorrect: The clinical features of congenital Zika syndrome includes microcephaly, facial disproportion, hypertonia/spasticity, hyperreflexia, seizures, ocular abnormalities, and sensorineural hearing loss. The mother has no history of travel, making Zika an unlikely source of this neonates congenital infection. 
❌ Exposure to blood products:
Incorrect: Exposure to contaminated saliva and blood is a potential source of infection with cytomegalovirus (CMV). Congenital CMV typically causes intracranial calcifications limited to the periventricular regions.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe left eye pain that started while he was at work. The patient is a radiologist and spends most of the day in a dark room reading films. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. Physical examination of the left eye is shown below. Intraocular pressure is 39 mmHg in the left eye and 18 mmHg in the right eye. Which of the following pharmacologic agents is contraindicated in the treatment of this patient’s condition?

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute left eye pain while in a low light environment. Physical examination demonstrates a moderately dilated pupil with surrounding injection and corneal cloudiness, as well as an elevated intraocular pressure. Together, these findings are consistent with acute closed-angle glaucoma. In this condition, medications that cause mydriasis (e.g. atropine) will worsen the angle closure and further impair aqueous humor outflow.

Treatment options for closed-angle glaucoma include medications that decrease aqueous humor production or increase outflow, as well as surgical management. Medications that decrease aqueous humor production include beta blockers (e.g. timolol), carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide), and alpha agonists (e.g., apraclonidine, brimonidine). Medications that increase aqueous humor outflow include cholinomimetics (e.g. pilocarpine) and prostaglandins (e.g., bimatoprost, latanoprost). If the patient’s disease is advanced or refractory to medical therapy, then laser iridotomy or trabeculoplasty can be performed.

Option Analysis

✅ Atropine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Timolol:
Incorrect: Timolol is a beta-blocker that is used to treat closed-angle glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor production.
❌ Acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to treat closed-angle glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor production.
❌ Pilocarpine:
Incorrect: Pilocarpine is a cholinomimetic agent that increases aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork and is used in the treatment of acute closed-angle glaucoma.
❌ Latanoprost:
Incorrect: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that increases the outflow of aqueous humor through the uveoscleral pathway. This medication is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. Although latanoprost is not routinely used in treating closed-angle glaucoma, it is also not contraindicated.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. The patient last visited the physician 3-months ago with difficulty seeing distant objects, especially at night, despite wearing glasses. She has recently been prescribed a new drug for her chronic eye condition. Past medical history is significant for open-angle glaucoma, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral narrowing of peripheral visual fields, cupping of the optic discs, and elevated intraocular pressure. Gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. Intraocular pressure is normal, but the darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes is observed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current examination findings?
questions.solution:
This patient was most likely started on topical latanoprost to manage open-angle glaucoma OAG). Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that increases the outflow of aqueous humor by decreasing the flow resistance through the uveoscleral pathway. It is the first-line treatment for OAG.

All the prostaglandin analogs (e.g., latanoprost and bimatoprost) may produce conjunctival hyperemia, hyperpigmentation of periorbital skin, eyelash growth, and permanent darkening of the iris (particularly in green-brown and yellow-brown irides).   

Option Analysis

✅ Topical latanoprost:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide is a first-line treatment for acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. It may cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis due to type 2 renal tubular acidosis. Other important adverse effects of acetazolamide include hypokalemia, sulfa allergy, and hyperammonemia with paresthesias.  
❌ Inhaled glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Inhaled glucocorticoids are associated with a hoarse voice, oral candidiasis, cough, and throat irritation. Darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes would not be observed.  
❌ Topical pilocarpine:
Incorrect: Pilocarpine, a cholinomimetic drug, can be used to treat open-angle glaucoma by increasing trabecular aqueous humor outflow. However, it is not the first-line treatment. Moreover, the most common side effects include cholinergic side effects (sweating, rhinorrhea, dizziness, and nausea), none seen in this patient.  
❌ Topical timolol:
Incorrect: Local side effects of topical timolol include dry eyes and superficial punctate keratopathy, neither of which is seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of severe left eye pain, blurry vision, nausea, and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and two myocardial infarctions that have led to substantial cardiac dysfunction. The patient was recently hospitalized for acute decompensated heart failure. Temperature is 36.8°C (98°F), pulse is 100/min,  respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 114/68 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 97%. Ophthalmologic examination reveals a firm, injected left globe and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil on the left. Gonioscopy shows that the iris meets the cornea at an angle of 10° (N = 20–45°). Topical pharmacotherapy is initiated with a drug that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium. The patient reports shortness of breath and difficulty lying down several hours later. Oxygen saturation is 80%. The patient appears obtunded. An audible S3 is heard on auscultation. Which of the following medications most likely provoked this acute presentation in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a unilateral red, firm, and severely painful eye with a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil and frontal headaches, vomiting, and nausea. These features are consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma. Beta-blockers (e.g., timolol. betaxolol, and carvedilol) are the first-line management option for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

In the eye, aqueous humor production is activated by a β receptor-mediated cyclic AMP–PKA pathway; β-blockade blunts adrenergic activation of this pathway. Another hypothesis is that β blockers decrease ocular blood flow, which decreases the ultrafiltration responsible for aqueous production.

Beta-blockers decrease the activity of G-alpha-s receptors in the ciliary body and lead to decreased aqueous humor production; however, since they can also depress cardiac function, beta-blockers are contraindicated in decompensated heart failure. Other side effects include worsening respiratory problems (asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), bradycardia, depression, and erectile dysfunction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide decreases aqueous secretion due to lack of HCO3–. It does not affect the heart and is unlikely to precipitate acute decompensated heart failure.  
❌ Latanoprost:
Incorrect: Latanoprost is an analog of prostaglandin F2α, which increases aqueous humor outflow via the uveoscleral pathway, thereby reducing intraocular pressure (IOP). Darkening of the iris, changes in the density, length, and color of eyelashes, and epithelial keratopathy are known side effects of long-term use of this drug.  
✅ Timolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Brimonidine:
Incorrect: Brimonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, can reduce intraocular pressure by increasing trabecular aqueous humor outflow and by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis. Side effects include blurry vision, ocular hyperemia, foreign body sensation, and pruritus. There are no alpha-2 receptors in the heart, which is the unlikely cause of acute decompensated heart failure in this patient.  
❌ Netarsudil:
Incorrect: Netarsudil is a rho-kinase inhibitor and is believed to reduce intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork. It is approved for topical use for open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a one-day history of severe left eye pain and blurred vision accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and headache. Three days ago, the patient visited his primary care physician and was prescribed a nasal decongestant for sinus congestion. Past medical history is significant for migraine, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and schizophrenia. Family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. Ophthalmologic examination shows decreased visual acuity. The left eye appears red, with a hazy cornea, shallow anterior chamber, and dilated fixed pupil. The left eye is stony-hard in texture. The rest of the neurological exam is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with sudden onset, unilateral eye pain and ipsilateral headache, nausea, vomiting, and blurred vision, combined with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil, suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma (AACG), most likely precipitated by pseudoephedrine (a sympathomimetic drug). Pseudoephedrine is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic receptor agonist, which can induce angle closure by mydriasis and diminished outflow of aqueous humor.

Anything causing pupillary dilatation can trigger an acute attack. Topical or systemic parasympatholytic agents (mydriatics, antihistamines), sympathomimetics (epinephrine, pseudoephedrine), dim illumination, and emotionally upsetting events have all been used been implicated as precipitating factors. Critically ill patients treated for respiratory failure with nebulized β-sympathomimetic and anticholinergic medications (e.g., albuterol and ipratropium) may develop AACG.

Management of ACCG involves medical control of elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) via timolol, apraclonidine, pilocarpine, or acetazolamide, followed by a reversal of angle-closure by laser peripheral iridotomy or other surgical treatments. The patient should be referred urgently to an ophthalmologist for care.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute migraine attack:
Incorrect: Acute migraine attack is characterized by a disabling headache associated with nausea and light and sound sensitivity. The cornea is clear, and pupillary size and response to light are normal. Visual acuity is unaffected. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
✅ Medication-induced mydriasis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Eye dehydration secondary to lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor and is the first-line medication for hypertension. It is unlikely to cause eye dehydration and precipitate angle-closure glaucoma as seen in this patient.  
❌ Bacterial conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: Bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by mild ocular pain. The cornea is clear, and pupillary size and response to light are normal. This patient’s presentation is most consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma.  
❌ Optic neuritis:
Incorrect: Optic neuritis is characterized by a sudden loss of vision (partial or complete), sudden blurred or "foggy" vision, and pain on movement of the affected eye, and can be seen in certain demyelinating diseases (e.g. multiple sclerosis). A fixed, mid-dilated pupil is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the office because of mild discomfort in his eyes. The patient is unsure of the onset. His vision remains unchanged. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Ophthalmological examination reveals increased intraocular pressure. Mental status and neurological examination are within normal limits. After discussing treatment options, the patient is initiated on timolol eye drops. This medication will improve this patient’s symptoms via the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with ocular discomfort and increased intraocular pressure most likely have open-angle glaucoma. Glaucoma is an optic neuropathy characterized by an increased intraocular pressure associated with increased aqueous humor production or decreased aqueous humor outflow. The patient is initiated on topical timolol, which is a beta-blocker used to treat glaucoma and acts to decrease the activity of Gα subunit receptors on the ciliary body and lead to decreased aqueous humor production. Glaucoma medications are summarized above.

In addition to medications, laser treatments are also available and includes:

  • Trabeculoplasty: a laser is used to open the trabecular mesh network which helps treat open-angle glaucoma.
  • Iridotomy is a laser used to punch a tiny hole in the iris, which helps treat closed-angle glaucoma.
Other laser treatments destroy the humor-producing cells, which reduces the production of the fluid, and in severe cases, sometimes they can be used to create a new channel through which the aqueous humor can be drained out.

On the other hand, implants shunt fluid out of the anterior chamber by bypassing the trabecular meshwork and collecting system.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Decrease aqueous humor synthesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase uveoscleral outflow:
Incorrect: Topical prostaglandins (e.g. latanoprost) increases the aqueous humor outflow via the uveoscleral pathway. Timolol is a beta-blocker.  
❌ Decrease retinal neovascularization:
Incorrect: Incropen-angulation of new blood vessels at the optic disc is the characteristic feature of diabetic retinopathy. Strict glycemic control, rather than a topical beta-blocker, decreases the risk of diabetic retinopathy. Additional therapies for reducing retinal neovascularization include intravitreal anti-VEGF agents, such as bevacizumab.  
❌ Ciliary muscle contraction:
Incorrect: Muscarinic agonists (e.g. pilocarpine) increase the outflow of aqueous humor via the contraction of the ciliary muscle and opening of the trabecular meshwork.  
❌ Increases trabecular outflow:
Incorrect: Muscarinic agonists (e.g. pilocarpine) increase the aqueous humor's outflow via the trabecular meshwork's ciliary muscle contraction and opening.
